In most cases it's not caused by anything serious and gets better over time.", "text": "

Back pain can be felt anywhere along your back. It's most common to have pain in your lower back.

You can usually treat back pain at home with gentle exercises and painkillers. See a GP if it does not get better after a few weeks.

Back pain can sometimes be caused by a problem with the joints, bones or tissues around the spine. But often there's no obvious cause.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/#symptoms", "description": "Back pain can be felt anywhere along your back. It's most common to have pain in your lower back.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/#treatments-summary", "description": "You can usually treat back pain at home with gentle exercises and painkillers. See a GP if it does not get better after a few weeks.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/#self-care", "description": "You can usually treat back pain at home with gentle exercises and painkillers. See a GP if it does not get better after a few weeks.", "text": "

The following tips may help reduce your\u00a0back pain and speed up your recovery:

  • stay as active as possible and try to continue your daily activities\u00a0\u2013 this is 1 of the most important things you can do, as resting for long periods is likely to make the pain worse
  • try\u00a0exercises and stretches for back pain; other activities such as walking, swimming,\u00a0yoga and pilates\u00a0may also be\u00a0helpful
  • take\u00a0anti-inflammatory painkillers, such as\u00a0ibuprofen \u2013 remember to\u00a0check the medicine is safe for you to take\u00a0and ask a pharmacist if you're not sure
  • use hot or cold compression packs for short-term relief\u00a0\u2013 you can buy these from a pharmacy, or a hot water bottle or\u00a0a bag of frozen vegetables wrapped in a cloth or towel will work just as well

Although it can be difficult, it helps if you stay optimistic and recognise that your pain should get better. People who manage to stay positive despite their pain tend to recover quicker.

", "title": "How\u00a0to relieve back pain"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/#treatments-other", "description": "You can usually treat back pain at home with gentle exercises and painkillers. See a GP if it does not get better after a few weeks.", "text": "

A GP, specialist or physiotherapist may\u00a0recommend extra treatments if they do not think your pain will improve with\u00a0self-help measures alone.

These may include:

  • group exercise classes\u00a0where you're taught exercises to strengthen your muscles and improve your posture
  • manual therapy\u00a0treatments, such as manipulating the spine and massage, which are usually done by a physiotherapist, chiropractor\u00a0or osteopath
  • psychological support,\u00a0such as\u00a0cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), which can be a useful part of treatment\u00a0if you're struggling to cope with\u00a0pain

Some people choose to see a therapist for manual therapy without seeing a GP first. If you want to do this, you'll usually need to pay for private treatment.

Surgery is generally only\u00a0considered\u00a0in the\u00a0small number of\u00a0cases where back pain is caused by a specific medical condition.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for back pain from a specialist"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/#causes", "description": "Back pain can sometimes be caused by a problem with the joints, bones or tissues around the spine. But often there's no obvious cause.", "text": "

It's often not possible to identify the cause of back pain. Doctors call this non-specific back pain.

Sometimes the pain may be from an injury such as a\u00a0sprain or strain, but often it happens for no apparent reason. It's very rarely caused by anything serious.

Occasionally back pain can be caused by a medical condition such as:

  • a\u00a0slipped (prolapsed) disc\u00a0\u2013 where\u00a0a disc of cartilage in the spine presses on\u00a0a nearby nerve
  • sciatica\u00a0\u2013 irritation of the nerve that runs from the pelvis to the feet

These conditions tend to cause additional symptoms, such as numbness, weakness or a tingling sensation, and they're treated differently from non-specific back pain.

", "title": "Causes\u00a0of back pain"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Back pain", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/back-pain/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Sciatica", ",", "pains and soreness", "Aches", "Back pain"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Back pain is very common and\u00a0usually improves within a few weeks or months.

Pain in the lower back (lumbago) is particularly common, although it can be felt anywhere along the spine, from the neck down to the hips.

In most cases the pain is not caused by anything serious and will usually get better over time.

There are things you can do to help relieve it. But sometimes the pain can last a long time or keep coming back.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How\u00a0to relieve back pain", "text": "How\u00a0to relieve back pain", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The following tips may help reduce your\u00a0back pain and speed up your recovery:

  • stay as active as possible and try to continue your daily activities\u00a0\u2013 this is 1 of the most important things you can do, as resting for long periods is likely to make the pain worse
  • try\u00a0exercises and stretches for back pain; other activities such as walking, swimming,\u00a0yoga and pilates\u00a0may also be\u00a0helpful
  • take\u00a0anti-inflammatory painkillers, such as\u00a0ibuprofen \u2013 remember to\u00a0check the medicine is safe for you to take\u00a0and ask a pharmacist if you're not sure
  • use hot or cold compression packs for short-term relief\u00a0\u2013 you can buy these from a pharmacy, or a hot water bottle or\u00a0a bag of frozen vegetables wrapped in a cloth or towel will work just as well

Although it can be difficult, it helps if you stay optimistic and recognise that your pain should get better. People who manage to stay positive despite their pain tend to recover quicker.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Getting\u00a0help and advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Getting\u00a0help and advice

Back pain usually gets better on its own within a few weeks or months and you may not need to see a doctor or other healthcare professional.

But it's a good idea to get help if:

  • the pain does not start to improve within a few weeks
  • the pain stops you doing your day-to-day activities
  • the pain is very severe or gets worse over time
  • you're worried about\u00a0the pain or struggling to cope

If you see a GP they will ask about your symptoms, examine your back and discuss possible treatments.\u00a0

They may refer you to a specialist doctor or a\u00a0physiotherapist for further help.

Alternatively, you may want to consider contacting a physiotherapist directly. Some NHS physiotherapists accept appointments without a doctor's referral, or you could\u00a0choose to pay for private treatment.

Read more about how to get access to physiotherapy.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments\u00a0for back pain from a specialist", "text": "Treatments\u00a0from a specialist", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A GP, specialist or physiotherapist may\u00a0recommend extra treatments if they do not think your pain will improve with\u00a0self-help measures alone.

These may include:

  • group exercise classes\u00a0where you're taught exercises to strengthen your muscles and improve your posture
  • manual therapy\u00a0treatments, such as manipulating the spine and massage, which are usually done by a physiotherapist, chiropractor\u00a0or osteopath
  • psychological support,\u00a0such as\u00a0cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), which can be a useful part of treatment\u00a0if you're struggling to cope with\u00a0pain

Some people choose to see a therapist for manual therapy without seeing a GP first. If you want to do this, you'll usually need to pay for private treatment.

Surgery is generally only\u00a0considered\u00a0in the\u00a0small number of\u00a0cases where back pain is caused by a specific medical condition.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes\u00a0of back pain", "text": "Causes\u00a0of back pain", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It's often not possible to identify the cause of back pain. Doctors call this non-specific back pain.

Sometimes the pain may be from an injury such as a\u00a0sprain or strain, but often it happens for no apparent reason. It's very rarely caused by anything serious.

Occasionally back pain can be caused by a medical condition such as:

  • a\u00a0slipped (prolapsed) disc\u00a0\u2013 where\u00a0a disc of cartilage in the spine presses on\u00a0a nearby nerve
  • sciatica\u00a0\u2013 irritation of the nerve that runs from the pelvis to the feet

These conditions tend to cause additional symptoms, such as numbness, weakness or a tingling sensation, and they're treated differently from non-specific back pain.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Preventing\u00a0back pain", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing\u00a0back pain

It's difficult to prevent back pain, but the\u00a0following tips may help reduce your risk:

  • do regular\u00a0back exercises and stretches\u00a0\u2013 a GP or physiotherapist may be able to advise you about exercises to try
  • stay active\u00a0\u2013 doing regular\u00a0exercise\u00a0can help keep your back strong; adults are advised to do at least\u00a0150 minutes of exercise a week
  • avoid sitting for long periods
  • take care when lifting\u00a0\u2013 read some\u00a0safe lifting tips
  • check your posture when sitting, using computers or tablets and watching television \u2013 find out how to sit correctly\u00a0and\u00a0get tips for laptop users
  • ensure the mattress on your bed supports you properly
  • lose\u00a0weight\u00a0through a combination of a\u00a0healthy diet and regular exercise if you're overweight\u00a0\u2013 being overweight can increase your risk of developing back pain
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to get immediate medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get immediate medical advice

You should\u00a0contact a GP or\u00a0NHS 111 immediately if you have back pain and:

  • numbness or tingling around your genitals or buttocks
  • difficulty peeing
  • loss of bladder or bowel control \u2013 peeing or pooing yourself
  • chest pain
  • a high temperature
  • unintentional weight loss
  • a swelling or a deformity in your back
  • it does not\u00a0improve after\u00a0resting or is worse at night
  • it started after a serious accident, such as after a car accident
  • the pain is so bad you're having problems sleeping
  • pain is made worse when sneezing, coughing or pooing
  • the pain is coming from the top of your back, between your shoulders, rather than your lower back

These problems could be a sign of something more serious and need to be checked urgently.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Bacterial vaginosis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bacterial vaginosis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bacterial vaginosis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a common cause of unusual vaginal discharge. BV is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI), but it can increase your risk of getting an STI such as chlamydia.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-11-22T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-11-22T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/", "name": "Bacterial vaginosis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-10T07:58:06+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/#overview", "description": "Bacterial vaginosis is a common condition that often causes smelly vaginal discharge.", "text": "

Symptoms of bacterial vaginosis include white and watery vaginal discharge that often has a strong fishy smell.

Bacterial vaginosis is usually treated with antibiotics from a GP or sexual health clinic.

You're more likely to get bacterial vaginosis if you're sexually active, have an IUD or use perfumed products around your vagina.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of bacterial vaginosis include white and watery vaginal discharge that often has a strong fishy smell.", "text": "

The most common symptom of bacterial vaginosis is unusual vaginal discharge that has a strong fishy smell, particularly after sex.

You may notice a change to the colour and consistency of your discharge, such as becoming greyish-white and thin and watery.

But 50% of women with bacterial vaginosis do not have any symptoms.

Bacterial vaginosis does not usually cause any soreness or itching.

", "title": "Check if you have bacterial vaginosis"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/#treatments-summary", "description": "Bacterial vaginosis is usually treated with antibiotics from a GP or sexual health clinic.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/#treatments-other", "description": "Bacterial vaginosis is usually treated with antibiotics from a GP or sexual health clinic.", "text": "

Bacterial vaginosis is usually treated with antibiotic tablets or gels or creams.

These are prescribed by a GP or sexual health clinic.

If you have a same-sex partner, they may also need treatment.

Recurring bacterial vaginosis

It's common for BV to come back, usually within 3 months.

You'll need to take treatment for longer (up to 6 months) if you keep getting BV (you get it more than twice in 6 months).

A GP or sexual health clinic will recommend how long you need to treat it.

They can also help identify if something is triggering your BV, such as sex or your period.

", "title": "Treatment for bacterial vaginosis"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/#self-care", "description": "Bacterial vaginosis is usually treated with antibiotics from a GP or sexual health clinic.", "text": "

To help relieve symptoms and prevent bacterial vaginosis returning:


Do

  • use water and plain soap to wash your genital area

  • have showers instead of baths


Don't

  • do not use perfumed soaps, bubble bath, shampoo or shower gel in the bath

  • do not use vaginal deodorants, washes or douches

  • do not put antiseptic liquids in the bath

  • do not use strong detergents to wash your underwear

  • do not smoke

", "title": "Things you can do yourself"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bacterial-vaginosis/#causes", "description": "You're more likely to get bacterial vaginosis if you're sexually active, have an IUD or use perfumed products around your vagina.", "text": "

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by a change in the natural balance of bacteria in your vagina.

What causes this to happen is not fully known, but you're more likely to get it if:

  • you're sexually active (but women who have not had sex can also get BV)
  • you have had a change of partner
  • you have an IUD (contraception device)
  • you use perfumed products in or around your vagina

BV is not an STI, even though it can be triggered by sex.

A woman can pass it to another woman during sex.

You're more likely to get an STI if you have BV. This may be because BV makes your vagina less acidic and reduces your natural defences against infection.

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a common cause of unusual vaginal discharge. BV is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI), but it can increase your risk of getting an STI such as chlamydia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Check if you have bacterial vaginosis", "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The most common symptom of bacterial vaginosis is unusual vaginal discharge that has a strong fishy smell, particularly after sex.

You may notice a change to the colour and consistency of your discharge, such as becoming greyish-white and thin and watery.

But 50% of women with bacterial vaginosis do not have any symptoms.

Bacterial vaginosis does not usually cause any soreness or itching.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you're unsure it's BV, check for other causes of unusual vaginal discharge.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if you think you have BV

The condition is not usually serious, but you'll need to be treated with antibiotics if you do have BV.

It's also important to seek treatment if you're pregnant as there's a small chance that BV can cause complications with pregnancy.

"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Sexual health clinics can help with bacterial vaginosis

Sexual health clinics treat problems with the genitals and urinary system.

Many sexual health clinics offer a walk-in service, where you do not need an appointment.

They'll often get test results quicker than GP practices.

During coronavirus, call a sexual health clinic if you need help or advice. Only go to a clinic if you\u2019ve been told to.

Find a sexual health clinic

"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at your appointment

Your GP or sexual health clinic will want to confirm it's BV and rule out an STI.

You'll be asked about your symptoms, and a doctor or nurse may look at your vagina.

A cotton bud may be wiped over the discharge inside your vagina to test for BV and other infections.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment for bacterial vaginosis", "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bacterial vaginosis is usually treated with antibiotic tablets or gels or creams.

These are prescribed by a GP or sexual health clinic.

If you have a same-sex partner, they may also need treatment.

Recurring bacterial vaginosis

It's common for BV to come back, usually within 3 months.

You'll need to take treatment for longer (up to 6 months) if you keep getting BV (you get it more than twice in 6 months).

A GP or sexual health clinic will recommend how long you need to treat it.

They can also help identify if something is triggering your BV, such as sex or your period.

To help relieve symptoms and prevent bacterial vaginosis returning:

Do

  • have showers instead of baths

Don't

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by a change in the natural balance of bacteria in your vagina.

What causes this to happen is not fully known, but you're more likely to get it if:

  • you're sexually active (but women who have not had sex can also get BV)
  • you have had a change of partner
  • you have an IUD (contraception device)
  • you use perfumed products in or around your vagina

BV is not an STI, even though it can be triggered by sex.

A woman can pass it to another woman during sex.

You're more likely to get an STI if you have BV. This may be because BV makes your vagina less acidic and reduces your natural defences against infection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy

If you develop bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy, there's a small chance of complications, such as premature birth or miscarriage.

But BV causes no problems in the majority of pregnancies.

Speak to a GP or your midwife if you're pregnant and your vaginal discharge changes.

Bad breath:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bad breath", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bad breath", "alternateName": ["Halitosis"]}, "description": "Find out what causes bad breath (halitosis), how to treat and prevent it, and when to seek medical advice.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bad-breath/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-01-10T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-01-10T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bad-breath/", "name": "Bad breath", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-01-17T14:11:25+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bad-breath/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bad breath"}], "keywords": ["Dental health", "Mouth and dental conditions", "Bad breath"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bad breath (sometimes called halitosis) is very common. You can usually treat it yourself.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How to treat bad breath yourself", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How to treat bad breath yourself

The best way of making sure you do not have bad breath is to keep your teeth, tongue and mouth clean.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • gently brush your teeth and gums at least twice a day for 2 minutes
  • use a fluoride toothpaste
  • gently clean your tongue once a day using a tongue scraper or cleaner
  • clean between your teeth with interdental brushes or floss at least once a day
  • get regular dental check-ups
  • keep dentures clean and remove them at night
  • use sugar-free mints or chewing gum after having strong-smelling food and drinks
  • try using an antibacterial mouthwash or toothpaste
"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not smoke
  • do not rinse your mouth with water straight after brushing your teeth
  • do not have lots of sugary foods and drinks
  • do not brush so hard your gums or tongue bleed
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Causes of bad breath", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of bad breath

Causes of bad breath may include:

  • eating or drinking strong-smelling or spicy foods and drinks
  • problems with your teeth or gums, such as gum disease, holes in your teeth or an infection
  • crash dieting
  • some medical conditions, like tonsillitis or acid reflux
  • smoking
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a dentist if you have:

  • bad breath that does not go away after treating it yourself for a few weeks
  • painful, bleeding or swollen gums
  • toothache or wobbly adult teeth
  • problems with your dentures
"}]}]}
Baker's cyst:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Baker's cyst", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Baker's cyst", "alternateName": ["Popliteal cyst"]}, "description": "Find out what a Baker's cyst is, what causes it, how it's treated and when to see your GP.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bakers-cyst/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-06-11T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-06-11T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bakers-cyst/", "name": "Baker's cyst", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-10-07T16:19:39+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bakers-cyst/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Baker's cyst", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bakers-cyst/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Baker's cyst"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A Baker's cyst, also called a popliteal cyst, is a fluid-filled swelling that develops at the back of the knee.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "Picture of Baker's cyst on leg", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/C0110412.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/429776/view", "datePublished": "2017-09-15T09:12:55+00:00", "keywords": []}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It's caused when the tissue behind the knee joint becomes swollen and inflamed. The swelling and inflammation can cause:

  • pain in the knee and calf
  • a build-up of fluid around the knee
  • occasional locking or clicking in the knee joint

However, sometimes a Baker's cyst may not cause any symptoms other than the fluid-filled swelling at the back of the knee.

A Baker's cyst can sometimes burst (rupture), resulting in fluid leaking down into your calf. This can cause sharp pain, swelling and redness in your calf.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What causes a Baker's cyst?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes a Baker's cyst?

Knee damage caused by a sports-related injury or a blow to the knee can lead to a Baker's cyst developing.

A Baker's cyst can also sometimes occur if you have a health condition such as:

  • osteoarthritis – usually caused by age-related "wear and tear" of joints; it particularly affects the knees, hips, hands and big toe
  • inflammatory arthritis – including rheumatoid arthritis, which is a less common type of arthritis and is caused by the immune system attacking the joints
  • gout – a type of arthritis that usually affects the big toe and is caused by a build-up of the waste product uric acid in the blood

Baker's cysts are more common in women than men, probably because women are more likely to develop osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. They usually develop in people aged over 40, although can affect people of any age, including children.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to see your GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see your GP

See your GP if you have a cyst that's causing problems and does not clear up on its own. They'll usually be able to diagnose a Baker's cyst by examining the back of your knee and asking about your symptoms.

Your GP will ask you whether you have any associated health conditions, such as arthritis.

Further tests may be recommended to rule out other more serious conditions, such as a tumour, an aneurysm (bulge in a section of a blood vessel) or deep vein thrombosis (DVT) (blood clot in one of the deep veins of the body). You may need an ultrasound scan or a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treating a Baker's cyst", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating a Baker's cyst

Treatment will not usually be necessary if you have a Baker's cyst that is not causing any symptoms.

Painkillers such as paracetamol and ibuprofen can be used to reduce the swelling and relieve any pain. Bandages or an ice pack may also help. A bag of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel works well as an ice pack.

If you have an underlying condition that's causing your cyst, it's important that the condition is properly managed. The cyst may disappear when the condition causing it has been treated.

In some cases, it may be possible to drain the cyst. Surgery may also be needed to repair any significant damage around the knee joint.

Read more about treating a Baker's cyst.

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bartholin's cyst", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bartholin's cyst", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out what a Bartholin's cyst is, what the symptoms and causes are, and the possible treatment options.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bartholins-cyst/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-07-23T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-07-23T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bartholins-cyst/", "name": "Bartholin's cyst", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-10T07:58:50+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bartholins-cyst/#overview", "description": "A Bartholin's cyst is a painless fluid-filled lump near the opening of the vagina.", "text": "

A Bartholin's cyst feels like a soft, painless lump near the opening of the vagina. Large cysts can cause pain when walking, sitting or during sex.

A Bartholin's cyst can happen when the tubes that help lubricate the vagina during sex become blocked.

You do not usually need to treat a Bartholin's cyst. If it's painful, soaking it in warm water, using a warm flannel and painkillers may help.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bartholins-cyst/#symptoms", "description": "A Bartholin's cyst feels like a soft, painless lump near the opening of the vagina. Large cysts can cause pain when walking, sitting or during sex.", "text": "

You may feel a soft, painless lump. This\u00a0does not usually cause any problems.

But if the cyst grows very large, it can become noticeable and uncomfortable. You may\u00a0feel pain in the skin surrounding the vagina (vulva) when you walk, sit down or have sex.

The cyst can sometimes affect the outer pair of lips surrounding the vagina (labia majora). One side may look swollen or bigger than usual.

If the cyst becomes infected, it can cause a painful collection of pus (abscess) to develop in 1 of the Bartholin's glands.

Signs of an abscess include\u00a0the affected area becoming red, swollen, tender and hot. It can also cause a high temperature of 38C or above.

", "title": "Symptoms of a Bartholin's cyst"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bartholins-cyst/#causes", "description": "A Bartholin's cyst can happen when the tubes that help lubricate the vagina during sex become blocked.", "text": "

The Bartholin's glands are a pair of pea-sized glands\u00a0found just behind and either side of the lips that surround the entrance to the vagina.

The glands are not usually noticeable because they're rarely larger than 1cm (0.4 inches) across.

The Bartholin's glands secrete fluid that acts as a lubricant during sex. The fluid travels down tiny tubes called ducts into the vagina.

If the ducts become blocked, they can fill with fluid and expand to form a cyst.

It's often not known why the ducts become blocked, but some cases are linked to sexually transmitted bacterial infections (STIs), such as gonorrhoea or chlamydia, or other\u00a0bacterial infections, such as Escherichia coli (E. coli).

", "title": "What causes Bartholin's cysts?"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bartholins-cyst/#treatments-summary", "description": "You do not usually need to treat a Bartholin's cyst. If it's painful, soaking it in warm water, using a warm flannel and painkillers may help.", "text": "

If you do not have any noticeable symptoms, it's unlikely you'll need treatment.

If\u00a0the cyst is painful, a GP may recommend some simple self care measures, such as soaking the cyst in warm water several times a day for 3 or 4 days and taking painkillers you can buy from a pharmacy or shop.

If these do not work, several treatments are available to treat the pain and any infection. If necessary, the cyst can be drained. Most of these treatments involve a minor surgical procedure.

A Bartholin's cyst can sometimes return after treatment.

A Bartholin's cyst, also called a Bartholin's duct cyst, is a small fluid-filled sac just inside the opening of a woman's vagina.

You may feel a soft, painless lump. This\u00a0does not usually cause any problems.

But if the cyst grows very large, it can become noticeable and uncomfortable. You may\u00a0feel pain in the skin surrounding the vagina (vulva) when you walk, sit down or have sex.

The cyst can sometimes affect the outer pair of lips surrounding the vagina (labia majora). One side may look swollen or bigger than usual.

If the cyst becomes infected, it can cause a painful collection of pus (abscess) to develop in 1 of the Bartholin's glands.

Signs of an abscess include\u00a0the affected area becoming red, swollen, tender and hot. It can also cause a high temperature of 38C or above.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to see a GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see a GP

Small Bartholin's cysts are sometimes only found during a routine cervical screening test or an examination carried out for another reason.

Always see a GP if you develop a lump in the area around your vagina so they can confirm a diagnosis and rule out more serious conditions.

If they think the cyst or 1 of your Bartholin's glands may be infected, they may use a swab to remove a sample of discharge for analysis to identify the\u00a0bacteria responsible.

In some cases, your GP may recommend you have a\u00a0biopsy. A small sample of cyst tissue will be removed and examined under a microscope to\u00a0check for signs of a rare\u00a0type of vulval cancer called Bartholin's gland cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes Bartholin's cysts?", "text": "What causes Bartholin's cysts?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The Bartholin's glands are a pair of pea-sized glands\u00a0found just behind and either side of the lips that surround the entrance to the vagina.

The glands are not usually noticeable because they're rarely larger than 1cm (0.4 inches) across.

The Bartholin's glands secrete fluid that acts as a lubricant during sex. The fluid travels down tiny tubes called ducts into the vagina.

If the ducts become blocked, they can fill with fluid and expand to form a cyst.

It's often not known why the ducts become blocked, but some cases are linked to sexually transmitted bacterial infections (STIs), such as gonorrhoea or chlamydia, or other\u00a0bacterial infections, such as Escherichia coli (E. coli).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How Bartholin's cysts are treated", "text": "How Bartholin's cysts are treated", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you do not have any noticeable symptoms, it's unlikely you'll need treatment.

If\u00a0the cyst is painful, a GP may recommend some simple self care measures, such as soaking the cyst in warm water several times a day for 3 or 4 days and taking painkillers you can buy from a pharmacy or shop.

If these do not work, several treatments are available to treat the pain and any infection. If necessary, the cyst can be drained. Most of these treatments involve a minor surgical procedure.

A Bartholin's cyst can sometimes return after treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who's affected", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who's affected

A Bartholin's cyst usually affects sexually active women aged between 20\u00a0and 30.

Bartholin's cysts do not usually affect children because the Bartholin's glands do not start functioning until puberty.\u00a0

The cysts are also uncommon after the menopause\u00a0as this usually causes the Bartholin's glands\u00a0to shrink.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Preventing Bartholin's cysts", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing Bartholin's cysts

It's not clear exactly why Bartholin's cysts develop, so it's not usually possible to prevent them.

But as some are thought to be linked\u00a0to STIs, practising safe sex (using a\u00a0condom every time you have sex) can help reduce your chances of one developing.

Get more advice about STIs

Bedwetting in children:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bedwetting in children", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bedwetting in children", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Bedwetting can be worrying and frustrating, but it's common for children to accidentally wet the bed during the night. The problem usually resolves in time.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bedwetting/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-04-27T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-04-27T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bedwetting/", "name": "Bedwetting in children", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-30T14:44:16+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bedwetting/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bedwetting in children"}], "keywords": ["Bedwetting"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bedwetting is common and often runs in families. It can be upsetting, but most children and young people will grow out of it. See a GP or school nurse for advice.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can do at home to help with bedwetting

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • give your child enough water to drink during the day

  • make sure your child goes to the toilet regularly, around 4 to 7 times a day, including just before bedtime

  • agree with your child on rewards for positive actions, such as a sticker for every time they use the toilet before bed

  • use waterproof covers on their mattress and duvet

  • make sure they have easy access to a toilet at night

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not punish your child \u2013 it is not their fault and can make bedwetting worse

  • do not give your child drinks containing caffeine, such as cola, tea and coffee \u2013 this can make them pee more

  • do not regularly wake or carry your child in the night to use the toilet \u2013 this will not help in the long term

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Bedwetting in young children is normal

Many children under the age of 5 wet the bed.

It can take some time for a child to learn to stay dry throughout the night.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you've tried things you can do at home and your child keeps wetting the bed
  • your child has started wetting the bed again after being dry for more than 6 months
"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments from a GP

The GP will be able to suggest other options such as:

  • a bedwetting alarm
  • medicine to reduce how much pee your child makes at night

The GP will check if treatment is helping. They'll also be able to offer support if you are finding it hard to cope.

If these treatments do not work, your child may be referred to a specialist.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of bedwetting

There are many reasons why a child might wet the bed. Causes include:

  • not feeling the need to pee while sleeping
  • making too much pee at night
  • stress at home or at school

Bedwetting may also be caused by an underlying health condition such as diabetes or constipation.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

More information and advice on bedwetting

  • Bladder & Bowel UK: Resources for children and young people
  • ERIC: Bedwetting
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}

"Beh\u00e7et's disease", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-14T15:16:43+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/behcets-disease/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Immune system", "Behcet's disease"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Beh\u00e7et's disease, or\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's syndrome,\u00a0is a rare and poorly understood condition\u00a0that results in inflammation of the blood vessels and tissues.

Confirming a diagnosis of\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease can be difficult because the symptoms are so wide-ranging and general (they can be shared with a number of other conditions).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms of\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease

The\u00a0main symptoms of\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease include:

  • genital and mouth ulcers
  • red, painful eyes and blurred vision
  • acne-like spots
  • headaches
  • painful, stiff and swollen joints

In severe cases, there's also a risk of serious and potentially life-threatening problems, such as permanent vision loss\u00a0and strokes.

Most people with the condition experience episodes where their symptoms are severe (flare-ups or relapses), followed by periods where the symptoms disappear (remission).

Over time, some of the symptoms can settle down and become less troublesome, although they may never resolve completely.

Read about the symptoms of\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Diagnosing\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease

There's no\u00a0definitive test that\u00a0can be\u00a0used to diagnose Beh\u00e7et's disease.

Several\u00a0tests may be necessary\u00a0to check for signs of the condition, or to help rule out other causes, including:

  • blood tests
  • urine tests
  • scans, such as X-rays, a CT scan or an MRI scan
  • a skin biopsy
  • a pathergy test \u2013\u00a0which involves pricking your skin with a needle\u00a0to see if a particular red spot appears within the next day or two; people with\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease often have particularly sensitive skin

Current guidelines state a diagnosis of Beh\u00e7et's disease can usually be confidently made if you've experienced at least 3 episodes of\u00a0mouth ulcers over the past 12 months and you have at least 2 of the following symptoms:

  • genital ulcers
  • eye inflammation
  • skin lesions (any unusual growths or abnormalities that develop on\u00a0the skin)
  • pathergy (hypersensitive skin)

Other potential causes also need to be ruled out before the diagnosis is made.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of Beh\u00e7et's disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of Beh\u00e7et's disease

The cause of Beh\u00e7et's disease is unknown, although most experts believe it's an autoinflammatory condition.

An autoinflammatory condition is where the immune system\u00a0\u2013 the body's natural defence against infection and illness\u00a0\u2013 mistakenly attacks healthy tissue.

In cases of Beh\u00e7et's disease, it's thought the immune system mistakenly attacks the blood vessels.

It's not clear what triggers this problem with the immune system, but 2 things are thought to play a role:

  • genes\u00a0\u2013\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease tends to be much more common in certain ethnic groups where the genes that are linked to the condition may be more common
  • environmental factors\u00a0\u2013\u00a0although a specific environmental factor has not been identified,\u00a0rates of Beh\u00e7et's disease are lower in people from an at-risk ethnic group who live outside their native country

Beh\u00e7et's disease is more common in\u00a0the Far East, the Middle East and Mediterranean countries such as Turkey and Israel.

People of Mediterranean, Middle Eastern and Asian origin are thought to be most likely to develop the condition, although it can affect all ethnic groups.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treating Beh\u00e7et's disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating Beh\u00e7et's disease

There's no cure for Beh\u00e7et's disease, but it's often possible to control the symptoms with medicines that reduce inflammation in the affected parts of the body.

These medicines include:

  • steroids\u00a0\u2013 powerful anti-inflammatory medicines
  • immunosuppressants\u00a0\u2013 medicines that reduce the activity of the immune system
  • biological therapies\u00a0\u2013 medicines that target the biological processes involved in the process of inflammation

Your healthcare team will create\u00a0a specific treatment plan for you depending on your symptoms.

Read about treating\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease

Specialist\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease centres

There are 3 NHS Centres of Excellence\u00a0that have been set up to help diagnose and treat people with Beh\u00e7et's disease in England.

These are located in London, Birmingham and Liverpool.

You may be referred to one of these centres so a diagnosis\u00a0can be confirmed. Staff at these centres may also liaise with specialists at other centres to help with a person's management and treatment, even if they're not seen directly.

You can find out more about these centres on the Beh\u00e7et's Syndrome Centres of Excellence website.

If you have\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease, your clinical team will pass information about you on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Further information about\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Further information about\u00a0Beh\u00e7et's disease

A natural response to receiving a diagnosis of a complex condition such as Beh\u00e7et's disease is to find out as much as possible about the condition.

However, in the UK this may be difficult because Beh\u00e7et's disease is so rare that many healthcare professionals know little about it.

A good place to start to learn more about Beh\u00e7et's disease is from Beh\u00e7et's UK \u2013 the UK's main patient support group for people with Beh\u00e7et's disease.

Its website has a range of information about different aspects of Beh\u00e7et's disease, a members' forum, blogs and links to other useful resources.

Bell's palsy:

Symptoms of Bell's palsy include weakness on 1 side of your face, a drooping eyelid or corner of your mouth.

Treatment for Bell\u2019s palsy includes a 10-day course of steroids, eyedrops and eye ointment. Treatment should start as soon as possible.

You cannot prevent Bell's palsy. It's thought to be caused by an infection. You can sometimes get it more than once.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bells-palsy/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of Bell's palsy include weakness on 1 side of your face, a drooping eyelid or corner of your mouth.", "text": "

See a GP if you have:

  • weakness or total paralysis on 1 side of your face that develops quickly within 72 hours
  • a drooping eyelid or corner of the mouth
  • drooling
  • a dry mouth
  • a loss of taste
  • eye irritation, such as dryness or more tears

These are symptoms of Bell's palsy.

It's important to see a GP as soon as possible after developing these symptoms.

This is because treatment for Bell's palsy is more effective if started early (within 72 hours).

You may also have a problem closing one of your eyes. If this is the case you may need additional treatment to prevent damage to your vision.

", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bells-palsy/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatment for Bell\u2019s palsy includes a 10-day course of steroids, eyedrops and eye ointment. Treatment should start as soon as possible.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bells-palsy/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatment for Bell's palsy includes a 10-day course of steroids, eyedrops and eye ointment. Treatment should start as soon as possible.", "text": "

Treatments for Bell's palsy include:

  • a 10-day course of steroid medicine
  • eyedrops and eye ointment to stop the affected eye drying out
  • surgical tape to keep the eye closed at bedtime

The GP might prescribe a type of steroid called prednisolone. Treatment with prednisolone should begin within 3 days (72 hours) of the symptoms starting.

Bell's palsy is rare in children, and most children who are affected make a full recovery without treatment.

", "title": "Treatment from a GP"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bells-palsy/#prevention", "description": "You cannot prevent Bell's palsy. It's thought to be caused by an infection. You can sometimes get it more than once.", "text": "

Because it's probably caused by an infection, Bell's palsy cannot usually be prevented. It may be linked to the herpes virus.

You'll usually only get Bell's palsy once, but it can sometimes come back. This is more likely if you have a family history of the condition.

", "title": "You cannot prevent Bell's palsy"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bells-palsy/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bell's palsy"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bell's palsy is temporary weakness or lack of movement affecting 1 side of the face. Most people get better within 9 months.

Unlike a stroke, the facial weakness develops gradually.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Call 999 if:

  • somebody's face droops on 1 side (the mouth or eye may have drooped)
  • a person cannot lift up both arms and keep them there
  • a person has difficulty speaking (speech may be slurred or garbled)

These can be signs of a stroke, which is a medical emergency.

Unlike Bell's palsy, the symptoms of a stroke usually come on suddenly.

How long Bell's palsy lasts

Most people make a full recovery within 9 months, but it can take longer. In a small number of cases, the facial weakness can be permanent.

Go back to see a GP if there are no signs of improvement after 3 weeks. Some cases might need to be treated with surgery.

Living with Bell's palsy can make you feel depressed, stressed or anxious. Speak to a GP if it's affecting your mental health.

You'll usually only get Bell's palsy once, but it can sometimes come back. This is more likely if you have a family history of the condition.

"headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A benign (non-cancerous)\u00a0brain tumour is a mass of cells that grows relatively slowly in the brain.

Non-cancerous brain tumours tend to stay in one place and do not spread. It will not usually come back\u00a0if all of the tumour can be safely removed during surgery.

If the tumour cannot be completely removed, there's a risk it could grow back. In this case it'll be closely monitored using scans or treated with radiotherapy.

Read about malignant brain tumour (brain cancer).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types and\u00a0grades of non-cancerous brain tumour", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types and\u00a0grades of non-cancerous brain tumour

There are many different types of non-cancerous brain tumours, which are related to the\u00a0type of brain cells affected.

Examples include:

  • gliomas\u00a0\u2013 tumours of the glial tissue, which hold and support nerve cells and fibres
  • meningiomas \u2013 tumours of the membranes that cover the brain
  • acoustic neuromas \u2013\u00a0tumours of the acoustic nerve (also known as vestibular schwannomas)
  • craniopharyngiomas \u2013 tumours near the base of the brain\u00a0that are most often diagnosed in children, teenagers and young adults
  • haemangioblastomas \u2013 tumours of the brain's blood vessels
  • pituitary adenomas \u2013\u00a0tumours of the pituitary gland, a pea-sized gland on the under surface of the brain

The Cancer Research UK website has more information about the different types of brain tumours.

Brain tumours are graded from 1 to 4 according to how fast they grow and spread, and how likely they are to grow back after treatment.

Non-cancerous brain tumours are grades 1 or 2 because they tend to be slow growing and unlikely to spread.

They\u00a0are not cancerous and can often be successfully treated, but they're still serious and can be life threatening.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms of non-cancerous brain tumours", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of non-cancerous brain tumours

The symptoms of a non-cancerous brain tumour depend on how big it is and where it is in the brain. Some slow-growing tumours may not cause any symptoms at first.

Common symptoms include:

  • new, persistent\u00a0headaches
  • seizures (epileptic fits)
  • feeling sick all the time, being sick, and drowsiness
  • mental or behavioural changes, such as changes in personality
  • weakness or\u00a0paralysis, vision problems, or speech problems
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to see a GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see a GP

See a GP if you have symptoms of a brain tumour. While it's unlikely to be a tumour, these symptoms need to be assessed by a doctor.

The GP will examine you and ask about your symptoms. They may also test your nervous system.

If the GP thinks you may have a brain tumour, or they're not sure what's causing your symptoms, they'll refer you to a brain and nerve specialist called a neurologist.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes of non-cancerous brain tumours", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of non-cancerous brain tumours

The cause of\u00a0most non-cancerous brain tumours is unknown, but you're more likely to develop one if:

  • you're over the age of 50
  • you have a family history of brain tumours
  • you have a genetic condition that increases\u00a0your risk of developing a non-cancerous brain tumour\u00a0\u2013 such as neurofibromatosis type 1, neurofibromatosis type 2, tuberous sclerosis, Turcot syndrome, Li-Fraumeni cancer syndrome, von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, and Gorlin syndrome
  • you've had radiotherapy

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treating non-cancerous brain tumours", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating non-cancerous brain tumours

Treatment for a non-cancerous brain tumour\u00a0depends on the type and location of the tumour.

Surgery is used to remove most non-cancerous brain tumours, and they do not usually come back after being removed. But sometimes tumours do grow back or become cancerous.

If all of the tumour cannot be removed, other treatments, such as radiotherapy and chemotherapy, may be needed to control the growth of the remaining abnormal cells.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovering from treatment for a non-cancerous brain tumour", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from treatment for a non-cancerous brain tumour

After treatment, you may have persistent problems, such as seizures and difficulties with speech and\u00a0walking. You may need supportive treatment to help you recover from, or adapt to, these problems.

Many people are eventually able to resume their normal activities, including work and\u00a0sport, but it can take time.

You may find it useful to speak to a counsellor if you want to talk about the emotional aspects of your diagnosis and treatment.

The Brain Tumour Charity has links to support groups in the UK, and Brain Tumour Research also has details of helplines you can contact.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bile duct cancer (cholangiocarcinoma)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bile duct cancer (cholangiocarcinoma)", "alternateName": ["Cholangiocarcinoma"]}, "description": "Understand more about bile duct cancer, its symptoms, when to get medical help, testing and diagnosis, treatment and where to find help and support.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bile-duct-cancer/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-05-05T14:42:00+00:00", "2023-05-05T14:42:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bile-duct-cancer/", "name": "Bile duct cancer (cholangiocarcinoma)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-19T09:47:54+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bile-duct-cancer/#overview", "description": "Bile duct cancer (cholangiocarcinoma) is a cancer that's found anywhere in the small tubes that connect the different organs in the digestive system.", "text": "

Symptoms of bile duct cancer include jaundice, losing weight, feeling tired, having a high temperature, feeling or being sick, and tummy pain.

Anyone can get bile duct cancer. You may be more likely to get it if you are over 65 or have a medical condition, such as liver cirrhosis.

Bile duct cancer is often treatable. Your treatment plan will depend on your situation. It may include surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bile-duct-cancer/symptoms/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of bile duct cancer include jaundice, losing weight, feeling tired, having a high temperature, feeling or being sick, and tummy pain.", "text": "

Bile duct cancer may not have any symptoms, or they can be hard to spot.

Symptoms of bile duct cancer can include:

  • your skin or the whites of your eyes turn yellow (jaundice), you may also have itchy skin, darker pee and paler poo than usual
  • loss of appetite or losing weight without trying to
  • feeling generally unwell
  • feeling tired or having no energy
  • a high temperature, or you feel hot or shivery

Other symptoms can affect your tummy, such as:

  • feeling or being sick
  • pain in your tummy
", "title": "Main symptoms of bile duct cancer"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bile-duct-cancer/causes/#causes", "description": "Anyone can get bile duct cancer. You may be more likely to get it if you are over 65 or have a medical condition, such as liver cirrhosis.", "text": "

Anyone can get bile duct cancer. It's not always clear what causes it.

You might be more likely to get it if you:

  • are over the age of 65
  • have certain medical conditions, such as abnormal bile ducts, long term swelling in the bowel (ulcerative colitis) or bile ducts, a parasite in the liver (liver flukes), bile duct stones and liver cirrhosis
", "title": "Who is more likely to get bile duct cancer"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bile-duct-cancer/treatment/#treatments-summary", "description": "Bile duct cancer is often treatable. Your treatment plan will depend on your situation. It may include surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bile-duct-cancer/treatment/#treatments-other", "description": "Bile duct cancer is often treatable. Your treatment plan will depend on your situation. It may include surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy.", "text": "

Bile duct cancer is often treatable. But it can be difficult to treat.

The treatment you have will depend on:

  • the size and type of bile duct cancer you have
  • where it is
  • if it has spread
  • your general health

It may include surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

The specialist care team looking after you will:

  • explain the treatments, benefits and side effects
  • work with you to create a treatment plan that is best for you
  • help you manage any side effects, including changes to your diet to help with your digestion

  • Bile duct cancer, also called cholangiocarcinoma, is a cancer that's found anywhere in the bile ducts.
  • The bile ducts are small tubes that connect different organs. They are part of the digestive system.
  • How serious bile duct cancer is depends on where it is in the bile ducts, how big it is, if it has spread and your general health.
