Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition that affects your moods, which can swing from 1 extreme to another. It used to be known as manic depression.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of bipolar disorder", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

People with\u00a0bipolar disorder have episodes of:

  • depression\u00a0\u2013\u00a0feeling very low and lethargic
  • mania\u00a0\u2013\u00a0feeling very high and overactive

Symptoms of bipolar disorder depend on which mood you're experiencing.

Unlike simple mood swings, each extreme episode of bipolar disorder can last for several weeks (or even longer).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Depression", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Depression

You may initially be diagnosed with\u00a0clinical depression before you have a manic episode (sometimes years later), after which\u00a0you may be\u00a0diagnosed with\u00a0bipolar disorder.

During an episode of depression, you may have overwhelming feelings of worthlessness, which can potentially lead to thoughts of suicide.

If you're feeling suicidal, read about where to get urgent help for mental health.

If you're feeling very depressed, contact a GP, your care co-ordinator or speak to a local mental health crisis team as soon as possible.

Find a local NHS urgent mental health helpline

You could also call NHS 111 if you're not sure what to do or if you cannot speak to your local NHS urgent mental health helpline.

If you want to talk to someone confidentially, call the Samaritans free\u00a0on 116 123. You can talk to them\u00a024 hours a day,\u00a07 days a week.

Or visit the Samaritans website or email jo@samaritans.org.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Mania", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Mania

During a manic phase of bipolar disorder, you may:

  • feel very happy
  • have lots of energy, ambitious plans and ideas
  • spend large amounts of money on things you cannot afford and would not normally want

It's also common to:

  • not feel like eating or sleeping
  • talk quickly
  • become annoyed easily

You may feel very creative and view the manic phase of bipolar as a positive experience.

But you may also experience symptoms of\u00a0psychosis, where you see or hear things that are not there or become convinced of things that are not true.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Living with bipolar disorder", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Living with bipolar disorder

The high and low phases of bipolar disorder are often so extreme that they interfere with everyday life.

But there are several options for\u00a0treating bipolar disorder that can make a difference.

They aim to control the effects of an episode and help someone with bipolar disorder live life as normally as possible.

The following treatment options are available:

  • medicine to prevent episodes of mania and depression\u00a0\u2013\u00a0these are known as mood stabilisers, and you take them every day on a long-term basis
  • medicine to treat the main symptoms of depression and mania when they happen
  • learning to recognise the triggers and signs of an episode of depression or mania
  • psychological treatment\u00a0\u2013\u00a0such as talking therapy, which can help you deal with depression, and provides advice about how to improve your relationships
  • lifestyle advice\u00a0\u2013\u00a0such as doing regular exercise, planning activities you enjoy that give you a sense of achievement, as well as advice on\u00a0improving your diet and getting more sleep

It's thought using a combination of different treatment methods is the best way to control bipolar disorder.

Help and advice for people with a long-term condition or their carers\u00a0is also available\u00a0from charities, support groups and associations.

This includes self-help and learning to\u00a0deal with the practical aspects of a long-term condition.

Find out more about living with bipolar disorder

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Bipolar disorder and pregnancy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bipolar disorder and pregnancy

Bipolar disorder, like all other mental health problems, can get worse during pregnancy. But specialist help is available if you need it.

Find out more about bipolar disorder in pregnancy

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What causes bipolar disorder?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes bipolar disorder?

The exact\u00a0cause of bipolar disorder\u00a0is unknown, although it's believed a number of things can trigger an episode.

These include:

  • extreme stress
  • overwhelming problems
  • life-changing events
  • genetic and chemical factors
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who's affected", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who's affected

Bipolar disorder is fairly common, and 1 in every 100 people will be diagnosed with it at some point in their life.

Bipolar disorder can occur at any age, although it often develops between the ages of 15 and 19 and rarely develops after 40.

Men and women from all backgrounds are equally likely to\u00a0develop bipolar disorder.

The pattern of mood swings in bipolar disorder varies widely. For example, some people only have a couple of bipolar episodes in their lifetime and\u00a0are stable in between, while others have many episodes.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Bipolar disorder and driving", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bipolar disorder and driving

If you have bipolar disorder,\u00a0it\u00a0may affect your driving. You must inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Social care and support guide

If you:

  • need help with day-to-day living because of bipolar disorder
  • care for someone regularly because they have bipolar disorder (including family members)

Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 10, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Birthmarks:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Birthmarks", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Birthmarks", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about birthmarks, including information about 6 of the main types, when to see a GP, and whether or not treatment is needed.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/birthmarks/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-02-04T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-02-04T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/birthmarks/", "name": "Birthmarks", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-06-26T10:00:04+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/birthmarks/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Birthmarks"}], "keywords": ["Skin,", "hair and nail conditions", "Moles", "Babies", "Birthmarks", "Spots", "Skin"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Birthmarks are coloured marks on the skin that are present at birth or soon afterwards. Most are harmless and disappear without treatment, but some may need to be treated.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Types of birthmark", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There are many different types of birthmark.

Flat, red or pink areas of skin (salmon patches or stork marks)

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "A baby's face with salmon patches on their eyelids and forehead", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/S_1017_stork-bite_M2700355.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/263023/view", "datePublished": "2017-10-18T15:39:32+00:00", "keywords": []}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Salmon patches:

  • are red or pink patches, often on a baby's eyelids, head or neck
  • are very common
  • look red or pink on light and dark skin
  • are easier to see when a baby cries
  • usually fade by the age of 2 when on the forehead or eyelids
  • can take longer to fade when on the back of the head or neck
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 3, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Raised red lumps (strawberry marks or haemangiomas)

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 5, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Strawberry marks:

  • are blood vessels that form a raised red lump on the skin
  • appear soon after birth
  • usually look red on light and dark skin
  • are more common in girls, premature babies (born before 37 weeks), low birth weight babies, and multiple births, such as twins
  • get bigger for the first 6 to 12 months, and then shrink and disappear by the age of 7
  • sometimes appear under the skin, making it look blue or purple
  • may need treatment if they affect vision, breathing, or feeding
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Red, purple or dark marks (port wine stains)

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "A port wine birthmark on a person's cheek, nose and upper lip", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/S_1019_port_wine_stain_C0461030.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "MID ESSEX HOSPITAL SERVICES NHS TRUST / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/1026532/view", "datePublished": "2019-10-03T16:12:35+00:00", "keywords": []}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Port wine stains:

  • are red, purple or dark marks and usually on the face and neck
  • are present from birth
  • look like very dark patches on dark skin
  • usually affect one side of the body, but can affect both
  • can sometimes be made lighter using laser treatment (it's most effective on young children)
  • can become darker and lumpier if not treated
  • can be a sign of Sturge-Weber syndrome and Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome, or macrocephaly-capillary malformation, but this is rare
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Flat, light or dark brown patches (cafe-au-lait spots)

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "Close-up of a flat, light brown patch on a person's skin", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/S_1019_cafe_au_lait_M2200030.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "DR P. MARAZZI / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/146602/view", "datePublished": "2019-10-03T16:12:35+00:00", "keywords": []}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Cafe-au-lait spots:

  • are light or dark brown patches that can be anywhere on the body
  • are common, with many children often having 1 or 2
  • look darker on dark skin
  • can be different sizes and shapes
  • may be a sign of neurofibromatosis type 1 if a child has 6 or more spots
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Blue-grey spots

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "Large, dark blue-grey patch that looks like a bruise on a baby's thigh", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/S_1017_mongolian_blue_spot_C0166926.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/520677/view", "datePublished": "2017-10-18T15:37:28+00:00", "keywords": []}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

These birthmarks:

  • can look blue-grey on the skin like a bruise
  • are often on the lower back, bottom, arms or legs
  • are there from birth
  • are most common on babies with darker skin
  • do not need treating and will usually go away by the age of 4
  • are not a sign of a health condition

If your baby is born with a blue-grey spot it should be recorded on their medical record.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Brown or black moles (congenital moles or congenital melanocytic naevi)

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Congenital moles:

  • are brown or black moles caused by an overgrowth of pigment cells in the skin
  • look darker on dark skin
  • can become darker, raised and hairy, particularly during puberty
  • may develop into skin cancer if they're large (the risk increases the larger they are)
  • do not need to be treated unless there's a risk of skin cancer
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Find out about other types of birthmark:

The Birthmark Support Group has information about other types of birthmark and getting help and support.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you're worried about a birthmark
  • a birthmark is close to the eye, nose, or mouth
  • a birthmark has got bigger, darker or lumpier
  • a birthmark is sore or painful
  • your child has 6 or more cafe-au-lait spots
  • you or your child has a large congenital mole

The GP may ask you to check the birthmark for changes, or they may refer you to a skin specialist (dermatologist).

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment for birthmarks", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most birthmarks do not need treatment, but some do. This is why it's important to get a birthmark checked if you're worried about it.

A birthmark can be removed on the NHS if it's affecting a person's health. If you want a birthmark removed for cosmetic reasons, you'll have to pay to have it done privately.

Possible treatments for birthmarks include:

  • medicines – to reduce blood flow to the birthmark, which can slow down its growth and make it lighter in colour
  • laser therapy – where heat and light are used to make the birthmark smaller and lighter (it works best if started between 6 months and 1 year of age)
  • surgery – to remove the birthmark (but it can leave scarring)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Bladder cancer:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bladder cancer", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bladder cancer", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Bladder cancer is where a growth of abnormal tissue, known as a tumour, develops in the bladder lining. In some cases, the tumour spreads into the surrounding muscles.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-05-10T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-05-10T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/", "name": "Bladder cancer", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-22T13:57:24+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bladder cancer", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-cancer/complications/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Complications"}], "keywords": ["Bladder cancer", "Cancer and tumours", "Bladder"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bladder cancer is where a growth of abnormal tissue, known as a tumour, develops in the bladder lining. In some cases, the tumour spreads into the bladder muscle.

The most common symptom of bladder cancer is blood in your urine, which is usually painless.

If you notice blood in your urine, even if it comes and goes, you should visit your GP, so the cause can be investigated.

Read about the symptoms of bladder cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and cancer:

  • Macmillan: Coronavirus guidance for people with cancer
  • Cancer Research UK: Coronavirus and cancer
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types of bladder cancer", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types of bladder cancer

Once diagnosed, bladder cancer can be classified by how far it has\u00a0spread.\u00a0

If the cancerous cells are contained inside the lining of the bladder, doctors describe it as non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer.\u00a0This is the most common type of bladder cancer.\u00a0Most people don't die as a result\u00a0of\u00a0this type of bladder cancer.

When the cancerous cells spread beyond the lining, into the surrounding bladder muscle, it's referred to as muscle-invasive bladder cancer.\u00a0This is less common,\u00a0but has a higher chance\u00a0of spreading to other parts of the body.

If bladder cancer has spread to other parts of the body, it's known as advanced or metastatic bladder cancer.

Read more about diagnosing bladder cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Why does bladder cancer happen?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Why does bladder cancer happen?

Most cases of bladder cancer appear to be caused by exposure to harmful substances, which lead to abnormal changes in the bladder's cells over many years.\u00a0

Tobacco smoke is a common cause and\u00a0it's estimated that more than 1 in 3 cases of bladder cancer are caused by smoking.

Contact with certain chemicals previously\u00a0used in manufacturing is also known to cause bladder cancer. However, these substances have since\u00a0been banned.

Read more about the causes of bladder cancer\u00a0and preventing bladder cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treating bladder cancer", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating bladder cancer

In cases of non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer, it's usually possible to remove the cancerous cells while leaving the rest of the bladder intact.

This is done using a surgical technique called transurethral resection of a bladder tumour (TURBT).\u00a0This\u00a0is followed by a dose of chemotherapy medication directly into the bladder, to reduce the risk of the cancer returning.

In cases with a higher risk of recurrence, medicine known as Bacillus Calmette-Gu\u00e9rin (BCG) may be\u00a0injected into the bladder to reduce the risk of the cancer returning.

Treatment for high-risk non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer, or muscle-invasive bladder cancer may involve surgically removing the bladder in an operation known as a cystectomy.

Most patients will have a choice of either surgery or a course of radiotherapy.

When the bladder is removed, you'll need another way of\u00a0collecting your urine. Possible options include making an opening in the abdomen so urine can be passed into an external\u00a0bag, or constructing a new bladder out of a section of bowel. This will be done at the same time as a cystectomy.

After treatment for all types of bladder cancer, you'll have regular follow-up tests to check for signs of recurrence.

Read more about treating bladder cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who is affected?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who is affected?

About 10,000 people are diagnosed with bladder cancer every year and it's the tenth most common cancer in the UK.

The condition\u00a0is more common in older adults, with most new\u00a0cases diagnosed in people\u00a0aged 60 and above.

Bladder cancer is also more common in men than in women, possibly because in the past, men were more likely to smoke and work in the\u00a0manufacturing industry.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Bladder stones:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bladder stones", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bladder stones", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about bladder stones and what causes them. Also, find out when to see your GP and how bladder stones are treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-stones/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-08-03T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-08-03T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-stones/", "name": "Bladder stones", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2018-10-03T20:00:12+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-stones/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bladder stones", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-stones/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bladder-stones/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Bladder stones"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bladder stones are hard lumps of minerals that can form inside the bladder when it's not completely empty of urine.

They may not cause any symptoms if they're small enough to be passed out of the bladder when you pee.

But most people with bladder stones do experience symptoms because the stones either irritate the wall of the bladder or block the flow of urine.

Typical symptoms of bladder stones include:

  • lower abdominal pain, which can often be severe (men may also have pain in or around their penis)
  • pain or difficulty when peeing
  • peeing more frequently (particularly at night)
  • cloudy or dark-coloured urine
  • blood in the urine 

Most cases of bladder stones affect men aged 50 or older because of the link with prostate enlargement. But both men and women can get bladder stones.

It's rare for bladder stones to affect children. In children, they can lead to bedwetting, and some boys may experience priapism, a persistent and often painful erection that can last for hours.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When to see your GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see your GP

See your GP if you experience any of the above symptoms, particularly if you have persistent abdominal pain, need to pee more frequently, or have blood in your urine.

These symptoms may not necessarily be caused by bladder stones, but need to be investigated further.

If your GP suspects you have a stone in your bladder, you'll be referred to hospital for testing. 

A blood and a urine test will probably be carried out first. A blood test will detect if there's an infection inside your bladder.

The next stage is to take an X-ray of your bladder. Not all types of bladder stones show up clearly on X-rays, so a negative X-ray result doesn't always mean that you don't have bladder stones.

An ultrasound scan may be used instead of an X-ray. Bladder stones can also be identified using a cystoscopy.

This is where a thin fibreoptic tube with a light and a camera at one end (a cystoscope) is inserted into the urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body) and moved up into the bladder.

The camera relays images to a screen, where they can be seen by the urologist (specialist in treating bladder conditions).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What causes bladder stones?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes bladder stones?

Bladder stones usually form when you can't completely empty your bladder of urine.

A common reason for this in men is having an enlarged prostate gland that blocks the flow of urine.

If urine sits in the bladder for a long time, chemicals in the urine form crystals, which harden into bladder stones.

Read more about the causes of bladder stones and who's at risk.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treating bladder stones", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating bladder stones

Surgery is usually needed to remove the stones from the bladder. The most common procedure is a cystolitholapaxy, where a thin tube (cystoscope) with a camera at the end is used to find the bladder stones.

The cystoscope will then use stone-crushing devices, lasers or ultrasound to break up the stones before they're removed.

Where possible, it's important to treat the underlying causes of bladder stones to prevent new stones developing in the future.

Read more about treating bladder stones.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Preventing bladder stones", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing bladder stones

If you have had bladder stones, they can come back. There are things you can do to try to prevent this happening.

You can try to:

  • increase your daily fluid intake to 2 to 3 litres to lower the concentration of your urine
  • regularly empty your bladder without delaying
  • urinate again 10 to 20 seconds after your first attempt (if you're unable to empty your bladder completely first time); this is called double voiding and helps empty the bladder more efficiently
  • avoid constipation (regular laxatives may be recommended)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "The bladder and kidneys", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The bladder and kidneys

The kidneys filter waste products out of the blood, which are mixed with water to create urine. Urine flows from the kidneys to the bladder, where it's stored.

When the bladder is full and you're ready to pee, urine passes out of your body through a tube called the urethra.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleedin:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding)", "alternateName": ["Rectal bleeding"]}, "description": "Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding) is often seen as small amounts of bright-red blood on toilet paper or pink water in the toilet. Find out when to get medical help if you keep bleeding from your bottom.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bleeding-from-the-bottom-rectal-bleeding/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-04-24T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-04-24T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bleeding-from-the-bottom-rectal-bleeding/", "name": "Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-12-02T22:46:32+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bleeding-from-the-bottom-rectal-bleeding/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding)"}], "keywords": ["Faeces", "Blood in bowel motions", "Diarrhoea", "Rectal examination", "Anal fissure", "Gastroenteritis", "Bowel cancer"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A small amount of one-off bleeding from the bottom is not usually a serious problem. But a GP can check.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if you're bleeding from the bottom

You might be bleeding from the bottom if you have:

  • blood on your toilet paper
  • red streaks on the outside of your poo
  • pink water in the toilet bowl
  • blood in your poo or bloody diarrhoea
  • very dark, smelly poo (this can be blood mixed in poo)

A small amount of one-off bleeding can often go away on its own without needing treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • your child has blood in their poo
  • you've had blood in your poo for 3 weeks
  • your poo has been softer, thinner or longer than normal for 3 weeks
  • you're in a lot of pain around the bottom
  • you have a pain or lump in your tummy
  • you've been more tired than usual
  • you've lost weight for no reason
"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Get advice from 111 now if:

  • your poo is black or dark red
  • you have bloody diarrhoea for no obvious reason

111 will tell you what to do. They can arrange a phone call from a nurse or doctor if you need one.

Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

Other ways to get help

Get an urgent GP appointment

A GP may be able to treat you.

Ask your GP practice for an urgent appointment.

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Go to A&E or call 999 if:

  • you're bleeding non-stop
  • there's a lot of blood – for example, you see large blood clots in the toilet
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at the GP appointment

The GP will check what's causing your symptoms.

They might:

  • check your bottom (rectum) with a gloved finger
  • ask for a sample of poo for testing
  • refer you to a specialist for tests
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Bowel cancer risk

Bleeding from the bottom is sometimes a sign of bowel cancer.

This is easier to treat if it's found early, so it's important to get it checked.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Common causes of bleeding from the bottom

If you have other symptoms, this might give you an idea of the cause.

Do not self-diagnose – see a GP if you're worried.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "Bright red blood on toilet paper, streaks on poo, pink toilet water", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Symptoms Possible causes
Bright red blood and pain when pooing, itchy bottom, lumps piles (haemorrhoids)
Bright red blood and pain when pooing – often after constipation a small tear in your anus (anal fissure)
Bleeding with or without lumps, itching or pain sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like genital warts, damage from anal sex
Bright red blood without pain side effect of blood-thinning medicine like warfarin or aspirin, broken blood vessels in the gut (angiodysplasia)
"}]}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "Blood in poo or blood with slime", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Poo can look like it's mixed with blood if you've eaten a lot of red or purple foods like tomatoes and beetroot.

But it's sometimes a sign of something else. A GP can check if you're worried.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Symptoms Possible causes
Blood and yellow slime when pooing, irritated anus, non stop bottom pain anal fistula
Bloody diarrhoea with clear slime, feeling and being sick tummy bug (gastroenteritis)
Bloody diarrhoea, tummy cramps and pain, feeling bloated an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) like ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease
Blood in poo bleeding in the anus, bowel or lower gut from injury or another problem
Blood in poo, change in pooing habits (like looser poo, diarrhoea or constipation), slime with poo bowel polyps, early signs of bowel cancer
"}]}, {"position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "Very dark or black blood or poo", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Poo can look very dark or black if you:

  • take iron tablets
  • eat a lot of dark foods like liquorice and blueberries

But it's sometimes a sign of something else. A GP can do a test to check this if you're worried.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Symptoms Possible causes
Dark or black poo bleeding in the stomach or gut – can be from injury or a side effect of blood-thinning medicine like warfarin or aspirin
Dark blood or poo with tummy pain or cramps stomach ulcer, diverticular disease and diverticulitis
Dark blood without pain blood-thinning medicine like warfarin or aspirin, angiodysplasia (broken blood vessels in the gut)
"}]}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}]}
Blood tests:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Blood tests", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Blood tests", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Everything you need to know about blood tests, including why and how they are done, with links to other useful resources.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blood-tests/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-10-26T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-10-26T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blood-tests/", "name": "Blood tests", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-02-04T19:00:47+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blood-tests/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Blood tests", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blood-tests/types/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Examples"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Immune system", "Blood tests"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Blood tests have a wide range of uses and are one of the most common types of medical test.

For example, a blood test can be used to:

  • assess your general state of health
  • check if you have an infection
  • see how well certain organs, such as the liver and kidneys, are working
  • screen for certain genetic conditions

Most blood tests only take a few minutes to complete and are carried out at your GP surgery or local hospital by a doctor, nurse or phlebotomist (a specialist in taking blood samples).

Read about some common types of blood test.

For more information about a wider range of tests, search the\u00a0blood test A-Z index on Lab Tests Online UK.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Preparing for a blood test", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preparing for a blood test

The healthcare professional who arranges your blood test will tell you whether there are any specific instructions you need to follow before your test.

For example, depending on the type of blood test, you may be asked to:

  • avoid eating or drinking anything, apart from water\u00a0(fasting) for up to 12 hours\u00a0\u2013\u00a0see can I eat and drink before having a blood test?
  • stop taking a certain medication \u2013 see can I take medication before having a blood test?

It's important to follow the instructions you're given, as it may affect the result of the test and mean it needs to be delayed or carried out again.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What happens during a blood test?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens during a blood test?

A blood test usually involves taking a blood sample from a blood vessel in your arm.

The arm is a convenient part of the body to use because it can be easily uncovered. The usual place for a sample to be taken from is the inside of the elbow or wrist, where the veins are relatively close to the surface.

Blood samples from children are often taken from the back of the hand. Their skin may be numbed with a special spray or cream before the sample is taken.

A tight band (tourniquet) is usually put around your upper arm. This squeezes the arm, temporarily slowing down the flow of blood\u00a0and causing the vein to swell. This makes it easier for a sample to be taken.

Before taking the sample, the doctor or nurse may clean the area of skin with an antiseptic wipe.

A needle attached to a syringe or\u00a0special container is\u00a0inserted into the vein. The syringe is used to draw out a sample of your blood. You may feel a slight pricking or scratching sensation as the needle goes in, but it shouldn't be painful. If you don't like needles and blood, tell the person who is taking the sample so they can make you more comfortable.

When the sample has been taken, the tourniquet will be released, and the needle will be removed. Pressure is applied to the skin for a few minutes using a cotton-wool pad. A plaster may be put on the small wound to keep it clean.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "After the test", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

After the test

Only a small amount of blood is taken during the test so you shouldn't feel any significant after-effects.

However, some people feel dizzy and faint during and after the test. If this has happened to you in the past, tell the person carrying out the test so they're aware and can help you feel more comfortable.

After the test, you may have a small bruise where the needle went in. Bruises can be painful, but are usually harmless and fade over the next few days.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Blood test results", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Blood test results

After the blood sample has been taken, it will be put into a bottle and labelled with your name and details. It will then be sent to a laboratory where it will be examined under a microscope or tested with chemicals, depending on what's being checked.

The results are sent back to the hospital or to your GP. Some test results will be ready the same day or a few days later, although others may not be available for a few weeks. You'll be told when your results will be ready and how you'll be given them.

Sometimes, receiving results can be stressful and upsetting. If you're worried about the outcome of a test, you may choose to take a trusted friend or relative with you. For some tests, such as HIV, you will be offered specialist counselling to help you deal with your results.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Blushing:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Blushing", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Blushing", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out how to stop yourself blushing and read about the possible causes and treatments.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blushing/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-03-28T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-03-28T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blushing/", "name": "Blushing", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-04-12T14:25:27+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blushing/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Blushing"}], "keywords": ["Hyperhidrosis", "Blushing"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Blushing is a common problem that can be embarrassing and affect your day to day life. There are things you can do to help stop it.

How to help stop yourself blushing

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • breathe deeply and try to relax – read about breathing exercises you can do to help reduce stress and anxiety
  • keep cool by removing a layer of clothing and drinking water
  • wear make-up that reduces the redness of your skin in stressful situations like an interview or when giving a presentation
"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not eat spicy foods or drink alcohol or hot drinks if they make you blush
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Common causes of blushing

Lots of different things can cause blushing. It's often caused by feeling embarrassed, hot or anxious.

Sometimes other symptoms you have might give you an idea of what's causing it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Symptoms Possible causes
A red face most of the time, small blood vessels can be seen under your skin, spots rosacea
Hot flushes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, low mood, reduced sex drive menopause
Sweating a lot, particularly in your armpits, hands, feet, face and groin excessive sweating
Swelling in your neck, anxiety and irritability, mood swings, difficulty sleeping, tiredness overactive thyroid
"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Some medicines can also cause blushing. Check the side effects of any medicine you're taking to see if blushing or flushing is listed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • your blushing is affecting your everyday life
  • you think your blushing might be caused by a medical condition or a medicine you're taking
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatments from your GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments from your GP

Treatment for blushing will depend on the cause.

For example, your GP may suggest:

  • a talking therapy like cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) if your blushing is caused by stress or anxiety
  • medicines to help reduce anxiety, stop blushing or treat an underlying condition

Very rarely, surgery may be an option if blushing is severe and other treatments have not helped. But this can cause serious and long-lasting side effects.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Bone cancer:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bone cancer", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bone cancer", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Primary bone cancer is a rare type of cancer that begins in the bones. Around 550 new cases are diagnosed each year in the UK.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cancer/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-04-26T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-04-26T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cancer/", "name": "Bone cancer", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-22T13:58:17+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cancer/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bone cancer", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cancer/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cancer/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cancer/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cancer/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Bone cancer", "Bone pain", "Cancer and tumours", "Bones"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Primary bone cancer is a rare type of cancer that begins in the bones. Around 550 new cases are diagnosed each year in the UK.

This is a separate condition from secondary bone cancer, which is cancer that spreads to the bones after developing in another part of the body.

These pages only refer to primary bone cancer. The Macmillan Cancer Support website has more information about secondary bone cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and cancer:

  • Macmillan: Coronavirus guidance for people with cancer
  • Cancer Research UK: Coronavirus and cancer
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Signs and symptoms of bone cancer", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Signs and symptoms of bone cancer

Bone cancer can affect any bone, but most cases develop in the long bones of the legs or upper arms.

The main symptoms include:

  • persistent bone pain that gets worse over time and continues into the night
  • swelling and redness (inflammation)\u00a0over a bone, which can make movement difficult if\u00a0the affected\u00a0bone is near a joint
  • a noticeable lump over a bone
  • a weak bone that breaks (fractures) more easily than normal

If you or your child are experiencing persistent, severe or worsening\u00a0bone pain, visit your GP. While it's highly unlikely to be the result of bone cancer, it does require further investigation.

Read more about the symptoms of bone cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types of bone cancer", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types of bone cancer

Some of the main types of bone cancer are:

  • osteosarcoma\u00a0\u2013 the most common type, which mostly affects children and\u00a0young adults under 20
  • Ewing sarcoma\u00a0\u2013 which most commonly affects people aged between 10\u00a0and 20
  • chondrosarcoma\u00a0\u2013 which tends to affect adults aged over 40

Young people can be affected because\u00a0the rapid growth spurts that occur during\u00a0puberty\u00a0may make bone tumours develop.

The above\u00a0types of bone cancer\u00a0affect different types of\u00a0cell. The treatment and outlook will depend on the type of bone cancer you have.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What causes bone cancer?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes bone cancer?

In most cases, it's not known why a person develops bone cancer.

You're more at risk\u00a0of developing it if you:

  • have had previous exposure to radiation\u00a0during\u00a0radiotherapy
  • have a condition known as Paget's disease of the bone \u2013 however, only a very small number of people with Paget's disease will actually develop bone cancer
  • have a rare genetic condition called\u00a0Li-Fraumeni syndrome\u00a0\u2013\u00a0people with this condition have a faulty version of a gene that normally helps stop the growth of cancerous cells

Read more about the causes of bone cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How bone cancer is treated", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How bone cancer is treated

Treatment for bone cancer depends on the type of bone cancer you have and how far it has spread.

Most people have a combination of:

  • surgery to remove the section of cancerous bone\u00a0\u2013 it's often possible to reconstruct or replace the bone that's been removed,\u00a0but\u00a0amputation\u00a0is sometimes necessary
  • chemotherapy\u00a0\u2013\u00a0treatment\u00a0with powerful cancer-killing medication
  • radiotherapy\u00a0\u2013\u00a0where\u00a0radiation is used to destroy cancerous cells

In some cases of\u00a0osteosarcoma,\u00a0a medication called mifamurtide may also\u00a0be recommended.

Read more about treating bone cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook

The outlook for bone cancer depends on\u00a0factors such as\u00a0your age, the type of bone cancer you have, how far the cancer has spread (the stage), and how likely it is to spread further (the grade).

Generally, bone cancer is much easier to cure in otherwise healthy people whose cancer hasn't spread.

Overall, around 6 in every 10 people with bone cancer will live for at least 5 years from the time of their diagnosis, and many of these may be cured completely.

Cancer Research UK has more detailed statistics broken down by the different types of bone cancer, see the\u00a0page on statistics and outlook for bone cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Bone cyst:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bone cyst", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bone cyst", "alternateName": []}, "description": "NHS information about bone cysts, including how they're treated and what causes them.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cyst/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-13T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-10-13T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cyst/", "name": "Bone cyst", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-20T09:55:39+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bone-cyst/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bone cyst"}], "keywords": ["Bone cysts"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bone cysts are fluid-filled holes that form in bones. They mainly affect children and teenagers. They're not usually serious, but they sometimes need to be treated with surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bone cysts are not always treated

A bone cyst may not need treatment if it's small and not causing any problems.

They often get better on their own, especially in children and teenagers.

You may have regular X-rays for a few years to check your bone is healing and the cyst is not getting bigger.

Treatments for bone cysts

A bone cyst might need to be treated if it's:

  • large or getting bigger \u2013 this could make the bone weaker and more likely to break (fracture) if you injure it
  • causing problems like pain, swelling or a lump

The main treatments are:

  • draining the fluid with a needle and injecting medicine into the bone to help it heal \u2013 this may need to be done several times over a few months
  • cutting or scraping out the cyst \u2013 the hole may be filled with small pieces of bone taken from another part of your body or from a donor, or with a bone cement mixture

Treatment is done under general anaesthetic. You will not usually need to stay in hospital overnight.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering after treatment

It normally takes at least a few months for the bone to heal.

You may need to avoid activities or sports that could damage the bone until it has healed.

You'll have regular X-rays for a few years to check it's getting better.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you get a lump, pain or swelling after treatment

This could mean the cyst has come back or you've developed an infection from surgery.

It's quite common for bone cysts to come back, especially in the first couple of years after treatment.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of bone cysts

The exact cause of bone cysts is unknown. They're not cancer and do not spread to other parts of the body.

The main types of cyst are thought to have different causes:

  • unicameral bone cysts \u2013 fluid-filled holes that may form if fluid does not drain properly from a bone as it's growing
  • aneurysmal bone cysts \u2013 blood-filled holes that may be caused by a problem with the blood vessels in a bone (possibly due to an injury or a non-cancerous growth)

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Borderline personality disorder", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Borderline personality disorder", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about borderline personality disorder. Personality disorders can cause a range of distressing symptoms and patterns of abnormal behaviour.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/borderline-personality-disorder/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-07-17T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-07-17T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/borderline-personality-disorder/", "name": "Borderline personality disorder", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-10T14:47:14+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/borderline-personality-disorder/#overview", "description": "Borderline personality disorder is a condition that affects how you think, feel and interact with other people.", "text": "

Symptoms of borderline personality include being emotionally unstable, having upsetting thoughts and acting without thinking.

The cause of borderline personality disorder is unclear. It's been linked to traumatic events during childhood, such as neglect or abuse.

The main treatment for borderline personality disorder is a type of talking therapy called psychotherapy.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/borderline-personality-disorder/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of borderline personality include being emotionally unstable, having upsetting thoughts and acting without thinking.", "text": "

The symptoms of BPD can be grouped into 4 main areas:

  • emotional instability \u2013\u00a0the psychological term for this is affective dysregulation
  • disturbed patterns of thinking or perception \u2013 cognitive distortions or perceptual distortions
  • impulsive behaviour
  • intense but unstable relationships with others

The symptoms\u00a0of a personality disorder may range from mild to severe and usually emerge in adolescence, persisting into adulthood.

", "title": "Symptoms of borderline personality disorder (BPD)"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/borderline-personality-disorder/#causes", "description": "The cause of borderline personality disorder is unclear. It's been linked to traumatic events during childhood, such as neglect or abuse.", "text": "

The causes of BPD are unclear. But as with most conditions, BPD appears to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

Traumatic events that occur during childhood are associated with developing BPD.\u00a0

Many people with BPD will have experienced parental neglect or physical, sexual or emotional abuse during their childhood.

", "title": "Causes of borderline personality disorder (BPD)"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/borderline-personality-disorder/#treatments-summary", "description": "The main treatment for borderline personality disorder is a type of talking therapy called psychotherapy.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/borderline-personality-disorder/#treatments-other", "description": "The main treatment for borderline personality disorder is a type of talking therapy called psychotherapy.", "text": "

Many people with BPD can benefit from psychological or medical treatment.

Treatment may involve a range of individual and group psychological therapies (psychotherapy) carried out by trained professionals working with a community mental health team.

Effective treatment may last more than a year.

Over time, many people with BPD\u00a0overcome their symptoms and recover. Additional treatment is recommended for people whose symptoms return.

Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is\u00a0a disorder of mood and how a person interacts with others. It's the most commonly recognised personality disorder.

In general, someone with\u00a0a personality disorder\u00a0will differ significantly from an average person in terms of how\u00a0he or she thinks, perceives, feels or relates to others.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of borderline personality disorder (BPD)", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The symptoms of BPD can be grouped into 4 main areas:

  • emotional instability \u2013\u00a0the psychological term for this is affective dysregulation
  • disturbed patterns of thinking or perception \u2013 cognitive distortions or perceptual distortions
  • impulsive behaviour
  • intense but unstable relationships with others

The symptoms\u00a0of a personality disorder may range from mild to severe and usually emerge in adolescence, persisting into adulthood.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of borderline personality disorder (BPD)", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The causes of BPD are unclear. But as with most conditions, BPD appears to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

Traumatic events that occur during childhood are associated with developing BPD.\u00a0

Many people with BPD will have experienced parental neglect or physical, sexual or emotional abuse during their childhood.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When to get medical advice", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you're experiencing symptoms of BPD, make an appointment with a GP.

They may ask\u00a0about:

  • how you feel
  • your recent behaviour
  • what sort of impact your symptoms have had on\u00a0your quality of life

This is to rule out other more common mental health conditions, such as depression, and to make sure there's no immediate risk to your health and wellbeing.

You may also find Mind a useful website.

Find out more about how BPD is diagnosed

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating borderline personality disorder (BPD)", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Many people with BPD can benefit from psychological or medical treatment.

Treatment may involve a range of individual and group psychological therapies (psychotherapy) carried out by trained professionals working with a community mental health team.

Effective treatment may last more than a year.

Over time, many people with BPD\u00a0overcome their symptoms and recover. Additional treatment is recommended for people whose symptoms return.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Associated mental health problems", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Many people with BPD also have another mental health condition\u00a0or behavioural problem, such as:

  • misusing alcohol
  • generalised anxiety disorder
  • bipolar disorder
  • depression
  • misusing drugs
  • an eating disorder,\u00a0such as\u00a0anorexia or\u00a0bulimia
  • another personality disorder,\u00a0such as antisocial personality disorder

BPD\u00a0can be a serious condition, and many people with the condition self-harm and attempt suicide.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Social care and support guide

If you:

  • need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability
  • care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled, including family members

Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support.
