{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Teeth grinding (bruxism)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Teeth grinding (bruxism)", "alternateName": ["Bruxism"]}, "description": "Read about teeth grinding (bruxism), where you rub your teeth together and clench your jaw. It's often stress- or anxiety-related and is treated with muscle-relaxation techniques or by using a mouth guard.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-05-04T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-05-04T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/", "name": "Teeth grinding (bruxism)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-03T15:48:55+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/#overview", "description": "Teeth grinding is where you rub your teeth together and clench your jaw, often without realising it.", "text": "

If you grind your teeth, you may get pain in your face or jaw, headaches or earache. Over time, you may damage your teeth.

Treatment for teeth grinding depends on the cause. You can get a special mouth guard that stops you damaging your teeth if you need it.

The cause of teeth grinding is not always clear. It's usually linked to things like stress, anxiety or sleep problems.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/#symptoms", "description": "If you grind your teeth, you may get pain in your face or jaw, headaches or earache. Over time, you may damage your teeth.", "text": "

Symptoms of teeth grinding include:

  • facial pain
  • headaches
  • earache
  • pain and stiffness in the\u00a0jaw joint\u00a0(temporomandibular joint) and surrounding muscles, which can lead to\u00a0temporomandibular disorder (TMD)
  • disrupted sleep (for you or your partner)
  • worn-down teeth, which can lead to increased sensitivity and even tooth loss
  • broken teeth or fillings

Facial pain and headaches often disappear when you stop grinding your teeth.

Tooth damage usually only happens in severe cases and may need treatment.

", "title": "Symptoms of teeth grinding"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatment for teeth grinding depends on the cause. You can get a special mouth guard that stops you damaging your teeth if you need it.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatment for teeth grinding depends on the cause. You can get a special mouth guard that stops you damaging your teeth if you need it.", "text": "

There are a number of treatments for teeth grinding.

Using a\u00a0mouth guard or mouth splint reduces the sensation of clenching or grinding your teeth.

They also help reduce pain and prevent tooth wear, as well as protecting against further damage.

Other treatments include muscle-relaxation exercises and sleep hygiene.

If you have stress or\u00a0anxiety, cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)\u00a0may be recommended.

", "title": "Treating teeth grinding"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/#causes", "description": "The cause of teeth grinding is not always clear. It's usually linked to things like stress, anxiety or sleep problems.", "text": "", "title": ""}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Teeth grinding (bruxism)", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/teeth-grinding/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Teeth"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Teeth grinding and jaw clenching (also called bruxism) is often related\u00a0to stress\u00a0or\u00a0anxiety.

It does not always cause symptoms, but some people get facial pain and headaches, and it can wear down your teeth over time.

Most people who grind their teeth and clench their jaw are not aware they're doing it.

It often happens during sleep, or while concentrating or under stress.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of teeth grinding", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of teeth grinding include:

  • facial pain
  • headaches
  • earache
  • pain and stiffness in the\u00a0jaw joint\u00a0(temporomandibular joint) and surrounding muscles, which can lead to\u00a0temporomandibular disorder (TMD)
  • disrupted sleep (for you or your partner)
  • worn-down teeth, which can lead to increased sensitivity and even tooth loss
  • broken teeth or fillings

Facial pain and headaches often disappear when you stop grinding your teeth.

Tooth damage usually only happens in severe cases and may need treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When to see a dentist or GP", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See a dentist if:

  • your teeth are worn, damaged or sensitive
  • your jaw, face or ear is painful
  • your partner says you make a grinding sound in your sleep

The dentist will check your teeth and jaw for signs of teeth grinding.

You may need\u00a0dental treatment if\u00a0your teeth are worn through grinding to avoid developing further problems, such as infection or a dental abscess.

See a GP\u00a0if your teeth grinding is related to stress. They'll be able to recommend ways to help manage your stress.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating teeth grinding", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There are a number of treatments for teeth grinding.

Using a\u00a0mouth guard or mouth splint reduces the sensation of clenching or grinding your teeth.

They also help reduce pain and prevent tooth wear, as well as protecting against further damage.

Other treatments include muscle-relaxation exercises and sleep hygiene.

If you have stress or\u00a0anxiety, cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)\u00a0may be recommended.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes teeth grinding?", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The cause of teeth grinding is not always clear, but it's usually linked to other factors, such as\u00a0stress, anxiety or sleep problems.

Stress and anxiety

Teeth grinding is most often caused by stress or anxiety\u00a0and many people are not aware they do it. It often happens during sleep.\u00a0

Medicines

Teeth grinding can sometimes be a side effect of taking certain types of medicine.

In particular, teeth grinding is sometimes linked to a type of antidepressant known as a\u00a0selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).

Examples of SSRIs include paroxetine, fluoxetine and sertraline.

Sleep disorders

If you snore or have a\u00a0sleep disorder, such as\u00a0obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA), you're more likely to grind your teeth while you sleep. OSA interrupts your breathing while you sleep.

You're also more likely to grind your teeth if you:

  • talk or mumble while asleep
  • behave violently while asleep, such as kicking out or punching
  • have sleep paralysis,\u00a0a temporary inability to move or speak while waking up or falling asleep
  • have\u00a0hallucinations, where you see or hear things that are not real, while semi-conscious

Lifestyle

Other factors that can make teeth grinding more likely, or make it worse, include:

  • drinking alcohol
  • smoking
  • using recreational drugs, such as ecstasy and cocaine
  • having lots of caffeinated drinks, such as\u00a0tea or coffee (6 or more cups a day)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Teeth grinding in children", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Teeth grinding can also affect children. It tends to happen after their baby teeth or adult teeth first appear, but usually stops after the adult teeth are fully formed.

See a GP if you're concerned about your child's teeth grinding, particularly if it's affecting their sleep.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Bird flu:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bird flu", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bird flu", "alternateName": ["Avian flu"]}, "description": "Bird flu, or avian flu, is an infectious viral illness that spreads among birds. In rare cases, it can affect humans.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bird-flu/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-05-18T06:49:00+00:00", "2021-05-18T06:49:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bird-flu/", "name": "Bird flu", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-02-04T11:56:27+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bird-flu/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bird flu"}], "keywords": ["Avian flu", "Bird flu"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bird flu, or avian flu, is an infectious type of influenza that spreads among birds. In rare cases, it can affect humans.

There are lots of different strains of bird flu virus. Most of them don't infect humans. But there are 4 strains that have caused concern in recent years:

  • H5N1 (since 1997)
  • H7N9 (since 2013)
  • H5N6 (since 2014)
  • H5N8 (since 2016)

Although H5N1, H7N9 and H5N6 don't infect people easily and aren't usually spread from human to human, several people have been infected around the world, leading to a number of deaths. H5N8 has not infected any humans worldwide to date.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Bird flu in the UK", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bird flu in the UK

No humans have been infected with H5N1, H7N9, H5N6 or H5N8 bird flu in the UK – this includes the type of H5N6 virus recently found in humans in China. Plans are in place to manage any suspected cases.

H5N8 bird flu has been found in some wild birds and poultry in the UK. H5N6 has also been found in some wild birds in the UK but is a different strain to that seen in China.

You can read the latest bird flu updates on GOV.UK.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How bird flu spreads to humans", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How bird flu spreads to humans

Bird flu is spread by close contact with an infected bird (dead or alive).

This includes:

  • touching infected birds
  • touching droppings or bedding
  • killing or preparing infected poultry for cooking

Markets where live birds are sold can also be a source of bird flu. Avoid visiting these markets if you're travelling to countries that have had an outbreak of bird flu.

You can't catch bird flu through eating fully cooked poultry or eggs, even in areas with an outbreak of bird flu.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Things you can do to prevent bird flu", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can do to prevent bird flu

If you're visiting a foreign country that's had an outbreak you should:

  • wash your hands often with warm water and soap, especially before and after handling food, in particular raw poultry
  • use different utensils for cooked and raw meat
  • make sure meat is cooked until steaming hot
  • avoid contact with live birds and poultry

What not to do:

  • do not go near or touch bird droppings or sick or dead birds
  • do not go to live animal markets or poultry farms
  • do not bring any live birds or poultry back to the UK, including feathers
  • do not eat undercooked or raw poultry or duck
  • do not eat raw eggs

There is no bird flu vaccine

The seasonal flu vaccine doesn't protect against bird flu.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of bird flu

The main symptoms of bird flu can appear very quickly and include:

  • a very high temperature or feeling hot or shivery
  • aching muscles
  • headache
  • a cough

Other early symptoms may include:

  • diarrhoea
  • sickness
  • stomach pain
  • chest pain
  • bleeding from the nose and gums
  • conjunctivitis

It usually takes 3 to 5 days for the first symptoms to appear after you've been infected.

Within days of symptoms appearing, it's possible to develop more severe complications such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Getting treatment quickly, using antiviral medicine, may prevent complications and reduce the risk of developing severe illness.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to seek medical advice

Call a GP or NHS 111 if you experience any symptoms of bird flu and have visited an area affected by bird flu in the past 10 days.

Your symptoms can be checked over the phone.

If you're abroad

Get medical help straight away if you get the symptoms of bird flu.

Contact your travel insurance company if you need advice about where to get help.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What a doctor can do

Tell the doctor if you have:

  • recently travelled to an area affected by bird flu and if you've been close (within 1 metre) to live or dead birds
  • had close contact (touching or speaking distance) with anyone who has a severe respiratory illness
  • had contact with anyone who died unexpectedly and was from an area that had an outbreak

These tests can be done to confirm bird flu:

  • a nose and throat swab to see if they contain the virus
  • if you're coughing up phlegm this may be tested for the virus

If the tests are normal, it's unlikely you have bird flu.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for bird flu

If it's thought you might have symptoms of bird flu you'll be advised to stay at home, or you'll be cared for in hospital in isolation from other patients.

You may be given an antiviral medicine such as oseltamivir (Tamiflu) or zanamivir (Relenza).

Antiviral medicines help reduce the severity of the condition, prevent complications and improve the chances of survival.

They are also sometimes given to people who have been in close contact with infected birds, or those who have had contact with infected people, for example family or healthcare staff.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Reporting suspected cases of bird flu", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Reporting suspected cases of bird flu

Bird flu is a notifiable disease in animals, so you should report any suspected case in animals to the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA), even if you're not sure.

Call the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) helpline on 03459 33 55 77 if you find dead wild birds.

To prevent infection it is important not to touch or pick up any dead or visibly sick birds that you find.

You can read more about notifiable diseases in animals and how to spot bird flu and what to do if you suspect it on the GOV.UK website.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Blood transfusion:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Blood transfusion", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Blood transfusion", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about blood transfusions, including when you might need one, how it's carried out and associated risks.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blood-transfusion/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-01-12T07:20:00+00:00", "2021-01-12T07:20:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blood-transfusion/", "name": "Blood transfusion", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-06-11T11:24:06+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/blood-transfusion/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Blood transfusion"}], "keywords": ["Blood transfusion"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A blood transfusion is when you're given blood from someone else (a donor). It's a very safe procedure that can be lifesaving.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Why it's done", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Why it's done

A blood transfusion may be needed if you have a shortage of red blood cells.

This may be because your body's not making enough red blood cells or because you have lost blood.

For example, you may need a blood transfusion if you have:

  • a condition that affects the way your red blood cells work – such as sickle cell disease or thalassaemia
  • a type of cancer or cancer treatment that can affect blood cells – including leukaemia, chemotherapy or stem cell transplants
  • severe bleeding – usually from surgery, childbirth or a serious accident

A blood transfusion can replace blood you have lost, or just replace the liquid or cells found in blood (such as red blood cells, plasma or cells called platelets).

Ask your doctor or nurse why they think you might need a transfusion if you're not sure.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What happens", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens

Before having a blood transfusion, the procedure will be explained to you and you'll be asked to sign a consent form.

A sample of your blood will also be taken to check your blood group.

You'll only be given blood that's safe for someone with your blood group.

During a blood transfusion:

  1. You sit or lie down in a chair or bed.
  2. A needle is inserted into a vein in your arm or hand.
  3. The needle is connected to a tube and a bag of blood.
  4. The blood runs through the tube into your vein.

It can take up to 4 hours to receive 1 bag of blood, but it's usually faster than this.

You can normally go home soon after, unless you're seriously unwell or needed a lot of blood.

How you might feel during and after

You might feel a sharp prick when the needle is first inserted into your vein, but you should not feel anything during the transfusion.

You'll be checked regularly while receiving the blood. Tell a member of staff if you feel unwell or uncomfortable.

Some people develop a temperature, chills or a rash. This is usually treated with paracetamol or by slowing down the transfusion.

Your arm or hand may ache and have a bruise for a few days after.

Contact a GP if you feel unwell within 24 hours of having a blood transfusion, especially if you have difficulty breathing or pain in your chest or back.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Risks", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Risks

Blood transfusions are common and very safe procedures.

All donor blood is checked before it's used to make sure it does not contain serious infections such as hepatitis or HIV.

There's a very small risk of complications, such as:

  • an allergic reaction to the donor blood
  • a problem with your heart, lungs or immune system (the body's defence against illness and infection)

The risks will be explained before having a transfusion, unless this is not possible – for example, if you need an emergency transfusion.

Speak to your doctor or nurse if you have any concerns.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Alternatives", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Alternatives

A blood transfusion will only be recommended if it's needed and other treatments will not help.

If it's possible that you'll need a transfusion (for example, if you're due to have surgery or you have anaemia), you may sometimes be given medicine to:

  • lower your risk of bleeding, such as tranexamic acid
  • boost your number of red blood cells, such as iron tablets or injections

These can reduce your chances of needing a blood transfusion.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Giving blood afterwards", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Giving blood afterwards

Currently, you cannot give blood if you have had a blood transfusion.

This is a precautionary measure to reduce the risk of a serious condition called variant CJD (vCJD) being passed on by donors.

Find out more about who can give blood on the NHS Blood and Transplant website.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bunions", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bunions", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Bunions are bony lumps that form on the side of the feet. Surgery is the only way to get rid of them, but there are things you can do to ease any pain they cause.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-08-24T11:30:00+00:00", "2023-08-24T11:30:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/", "name": "Bunions", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-28T11:40:19+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/#overview", "description": "Bunions are bony lumps that form on the side of the feet.", "text": "

The main symptoms of bunions are hard lumps on the side of your feet near your toes. Your big toe might also point towards your other toes.

Surgery is the only way to get rid of bunions, but things like wearing comfortable shoes and using insoles or toe supports can help ease any pain.

It's not clear if you can prevent bunions. Things like wearing the correct shoe size and avoiding shoes with pointy toes may help.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/#symptoms", "description": "The main symptoms of bunions are hard lumps on the side of your feet near your toes. Your big toe might also point towards your other toes.", "text": "

Symptoms of bunions include:


Hard lumps on the sides of your feet, by your big toes


Your big toe pointing towards your other toes


Hard, red or swollen skin. On dark skin, the bunion may look darker than the surrounding skin

You may also have pain along the side or bottom of your feet. This is usually worse when wearing shoes and walking.

", "title": "Check if you have bunions"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/#treatments-summary", "description": "Surgery is the only way to get rid of bunions, but things like wearing comfortable shoes and using insoles or toe supports can help ease any pain.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/#self-care", "description": "Surgery is the only way to get rid of bunions, but things like wearing comfortable shoes and using insoles or toe supports can help ease any pain.", "text": "

You cannot get rid of bunions or stop them getting worse yourself, but there are things you can do to relieve any pain:


Do

  • wear wide shoes with a low heel and soft sole

  • hold an ice pack (or a bag of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel) to the bunion for up to 5 minutes at a time

  • try bunion pads (soft pads you put in shoes to stop them rubbing on a bunion) – you can buy these from pharmacies

  • take paracetamol or ibuprofen

  • try to lose weight if you're overweight


Don't

  • do not wear high heels or tight, pointy shoes

", "title": "How to ease bunion pain yourself"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/#treatments-other", "description": "Surgery is the only way to get rid of bunions, but things like wearing comfortable shoes and using insoles or toe supports can help ease any pain.", "text": "

A GP or podiatrist can advise you about:

  • things you can do to ease your symptoms
  • things you can buy or have specially made to reduce bunion pain, such as insoles (orthotics), toe spacers and toe supports (splints)

A GP may refer you to a surgeon if your bunions are very painful or having a big effect on your life.

Surgery is not done just to improve how your feet look.

", "title": "Treatments for a bunion from a GP or podiatrist"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bunions/#prevention", "description": "It's not clear if you can prevent bunions. The cause of bunions is unknown. It's not clear if you can do anything to prevent them.

It might help to:

  • make sure your shoes are the correct size and have enough room for your toes
  • avoid shoes with high heels or pointy toes

See a GP if:

  • the pain has not improved after trying home treatments for a few weeks
  • the pain is stopping you doing your normal activities
  • your bunions are getting worse
  • you also have diabetes – foot problems can be more serious if you have diabetes
"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The GP might refer you to a foot specialist (podiatrist).

You can also pay to see a foot specialist privately.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Find a service", "identifier": "2", "text": "

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments for a bunion from a GP or podiatrist", "text": "Treatment from a GP or podiatrist", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A GP or podiatrist can advise you about:

  • things you can do to ease your symptoms
  • things you can buy or have specially made to reduce bunion pain, such as insoles (orthotics), toe spacers and toe supports (splints)

A GP may refer you to a surgeon if your bunions are very painful or having a big effect on your life.

Surgery is not done just to improve how your feet look.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Surgery for bunions

Surgery is the only way to get rid of bunions.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "What happens during bunion surgery", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The main operation for bunions is an osteotomy.

This involves:

  1. Making a small cut in the skin over your big toe.
  2. Cutting or scraping away the bunion.
  3. Straightening your toe bone.
  4. Fixing your toe bone in place with metal screws or staples put under your skin. These are often left in permanently.

Surgery is usually done when you're asleep under general anaesthetic.

Most people go home the same day.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It can take a while to recover from surgery.

You'll usually need to:

  • stay off your feet as much as possible for at least 2 weeks
  • avoid driving for 6 to 8 weeks
  • stay off work for 6 to 12 weeks
  • avoid sports for up to 6 months

After the operation:

  • your toes might be weaker or stiffer than before
  • they may not be perfectly straight
  • your feet might still be slightly wide, so you'll probably have to keep wearing wide, comfy shoes

Bunions sometimes come back after surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "You cannot always prevent bunions", "text": "Causes and prevention", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The cause of bunions is unknown. It's not clear if you can do anything to prevent them.

It might help to:

  • make sure your shoes are the correct size and have enough room for your toes
  • avoid shoes with high heels or pointy toes
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Biological and biosimilar medicines (bio:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Biological and biosimilar medicines (biosimilars)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Biological and biosimilar medicines (biosimilars)", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about biological medicines, which are used to treat some long-term medical conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, uveitis, Crohn's disease, psoriasis and ankylosing spondylitis.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/biological-and-biosimilar-medicines/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-11-06T10:53:00+00:00", "2023-11-06T10:53:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/biological-and-biosimilar-medicines/", "name": "Biological and biosimilar medicines (biosimilars)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-23T11:20:23+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/biological-and-biosimilar-medicines/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Biological and biosimilar medicines (biosimilars)"}], "keywords": ["biologicals", "biosimilars", "Biologics"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A biological medicine, or biologic, is a type of hospital treatment for some long-term medical conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, psoriasis, uveitis and ankylosing spondylitis.

The medicine is made from proteins and other substances produced by the body.

It's a liquid that's given through a drip or injection pen.

A biosimilar is a newer version of the original biological medicine. It works in the same way.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and biological and biosimilar medicines from Arthritis and Musculoskeletal Alliance (ARMA)

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Why use biosimilars?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Why use biosimilars?

Biosimilar medicines generally cost less than the "original brand" biological medicine, but they're just as safe and effective.

Switching patients from the original biological medicine to a biosimilar could save the NHS hundreds of millions of pounds.

And you should not notice any difference \u2013 your body should respond in the same way to the newer version of the medicine.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Are biosimilars safe?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Are biosimilars safe?

Biosimilars are thoroughly tested in clinical trials to show they work just as well and are just as safe as the original biological medicine.

To be used in the UK, biosimilars must be approved and licensed in the same way as all medicines.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Are biosimilars the same as generics?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Are biosimilars the same as generics?

No. Generics are exact copies of the original medicine \u2013 for example, a supermarket-brand ibuprofen is the generic version or copy of Nurofen.

Biosimilars are not generics because they are not completely identical to the original medicine. But they're just as safe and effective.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Switching to a biosimilar version of adalimumab (Humira)", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Switching to a biosimilar version of adalimumab (Humira)

Adalimumab is a biological medicine used to treat inflammatory conditions, such as Crohn's disease, psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis.

The brand name of the original drug is Humira.

If you have been taking adalimumab (Humira) and your hospital decides to start using biosimilars, you should receive a letter explaining this.

It should give details of who you can contact if you have any questions.

You should be offered a conversation with your doctor or specialist nurse before you're prescribed a biosimilar.

Any decision to switch to a biosimilar will take into account your needs and preferences, as well as the available clinical evidence.

Together with your doctor or nurse, you can agree on the best medicine for you. In some cases this may mean continuing with Humira and not switching.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "More information", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Find out how to treat and avoid spreading them, and when to get medical help.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-12-07T11:26:00+00:00", "2023-12-07T11:26:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/", "name": "Diarrhoea and vomiting", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2021-01-18T11:27:00+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/#overview", "description": "Diarrhoea and vomiting are common in adults, children and babies. They're often caused by a stomach bug and should stop in a few days.", "text": "

To avoid spreading any infection, stay off school or work until you've not been sick or had diarrhoea for at least 2 days. Wash your hands often.

The most common causes of diarrhoea and vomiting are a stomach bug, norovirus and food poisoning.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/#self-care", "description": "Diarrhoea and vomiting can usually be treated at home. It's important to get plenty of rest and drink lots of fluids to avoid dehydration.", "text": "

You can usually treat yourself or your child at home. The most important thing is to have lots of fluids to avoid dehydration.


Do

  • stay at home and get plenty of rest

  • drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash – take small sips if you feel sick

  • carry on breast or bottle feeding your baby – if they're being sick, try giving small feeds more often than usual

  • give babies on formula or solid foods small sips of water between feeds

  • eat when you feel able to – you do not need to eat or avoid any specific foods

  • take paracetamol if you're in discomfort – check the leaflet before giving it to your child


Don't

  • do not have fruit juice or fizzy drinks – they can make diarrhoea worse

  • do not make baby formula weaker – use it at its usual strength

  • do not give children under 12 medicine to stop diarrhoea

  • do not give aspirin to children under 16

", "title": "How to treat diarrhoea and vomiting yourself"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/#prevention", "description": "To avoid spreading any infection, stay off school or work until you've not been sick or had diarrhoea for at least 2 days. Wash your hands often.", "text": "

Important

Stay off school or work until you've not been sick or had diarrhoea for at least 2 days.

To help avoid spreading an infection:


Do

  • wash your hands with soap and water frequently

  • wash any clothing or bedding that has poo or vomit on it separately on a hot wash

  • clean toilet seats, flush handles, taps, surfaces and door handles every day


Don't

  • do not prepare food for other people, if possible

  • do not share towels, flannels, cutlery or utensils

  • do not use a swimming pool until 2 weeks after the symptoms stop

", "title": "Diarrhoea and vomiting can spread easily"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "nonurgent_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/#non-urgent-medical-help", "description": "You can get medicines from a pharmacy to help with diarrhoea and vomiting, such as rehydration sachets that stop you becoming dehydrated.", "text": "

Speak to a pharmacist if:

  • you or your child (over 5 years) have signs of dehydration – such as dark, smelly pee or peeing less than usual
  • you need to stop diarrhoea for a few hours

They may recommend:

  • oral rehydration sachets you mix with water to make a drink
  • medicine to stop diarrhoea for a few hours (like loperamide) – not suitable for children under 12

Call your pharmacy or contact them online before going in person. You can get medicines delivered or ask someone to collect them.

", "title": "A pharmacist can help with diarrhoea and vomiting"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "urgent_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/#urgent-medical-help", "description": "", "text": "

Get advice from 111 now if:

  • you're worried about a baby under 12 months
  • your child stops breast or bottle feeding while they're ill
  • a child under 5 years has signs of dehydration – such as fewer wet nappies
  • you or your child (over 5 years) still have signs of dehydration after using oral rehydration sachets
  • you or your child keep being sick and cannot keep fluid down
  • you or your child have bloody diarrhoea or bleeding from the bottom
  • you or your child have diarrhoea for more than 7 days or vomiting for more than 2 days

111 will tell you what to do. They can arrange a phone call from a nurse or doctor if you need one.

Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

Other ways to get help

Get an urgent GP appointment

A GP may be able to help you.

Ask your GP practice for an urgent appointment.

Check with the GP surgery before going in. A GP may speak to you on the phone.

", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "emergency_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/#emergency-medical-help", "description": "", "text": "

Call 999 or go to A&E if you or your child:

  • vomit blood or have vomit that looks like ground coffee
  • have bright green or yellow vomit
  • might have swallowed something poisonous
  • have a stiff neck and pain when looking at bright lights
  • have a sudden, severe headache or stomach ache
What we mean by severe pain
Severe pain:
  • always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk
  • you cannot sleep
  • it's very hard to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash or dress
Moderate pain:
  • always there
  • makes it hard to concentrate or sleep
  • you can manage to get up, wash or dress
Mild pain:
  • comes and goes
  • is annoying but does not stop you doing things like going to work
", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diarrhoea-and-vomiting/#causes", "description": "The most common causes of diarrhoea and vomiting are a stomach bug, norovirus and food poisoning.", "text": "

You probably will not know exactly what the cause is, but the main causes of diarrhoea and vomiting are treated in the same way.

The most common causes are:

  • a stomach bug (gastroenteritis)
  • norovirus – also called the "vomiting bug"
  • food poisoning
Other causes of diarrhoea or vomiting

Diarrhoea can also be caused by:

  • medicines – check the leaflet to see if it's a side effect
  • a food intolerance or food allergy
  • irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
  • inflammatory bowel disease
  • coeliac disease
  • diverticular disease

Vomiting can also be caused by:

  • pregnancy
  • migraine
  • labyrinthitis
  • medicines – check the leaflet to see if it's a side effect
  • reflux – where a baby brings feeds back up ("spitting up")
  • other infections – such as a urinary tract infection (UTI)

Diarrhoea and vomiting are common in adults, children and babies. They're often caused by a stomach bug and should stop in a few days.

The advice is the same if you have diarrhoea and vomiting together or separately.

Bullous pemphigoid is a rare skin condition that causes itching, redness and blisters. It may last a few years and sometimes causes serious problems, but treatment can help.

Check if you have bullous pemphigoid

MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/260961/view", "datePublished": "2017-09-25T10:27:12+00:00", "keywords": []}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Not everyone gets blisters. If you do, they may keep coming and going for months or years.

There are several other causes of blisters if you're not sure it's bullous pemphigoid.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you have an itchy red rash that doesn't go away in a few weeks
  • you have lots of blisters, or big, painful blisters
  • you have blisters that keep coming back
  • your skin is red, hot and swollen, or a blister is filled with green or yellow pus

A GP can check what the cause might be.

If they think it could be bullous pemphigoid, they may refer you to a specialist for tests and treatment.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for bullous pemphigoid

Bullous pemphigoid eventually goes away on its own, but it can last a few years.

Treatment can help your skin heal, stop new patches or blisters appearing, and reduce the risk of your skin getting infected.

The main treatments are:

  • steroid creams
  • steroid tablets
  • antibiotics

Your skin should eventually heal without scarring, but it might be a bit darker than it was before.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Important

Do not burst your blisters – your skin might get infected.

If a blister is in an annoying place (like the bottom of your foot), your doctor can drain it with a needle.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Risks", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bullous pemphigoid can be serious

Even with treatment, bullous pemphigoid can sometimes cause serious problems.

The main risks are:

  • skin infections – these can be very serious if they get deeper into your body (sepsis)
  • side effects of steroid treatment – including high blood pressure, weakened bones and a higher risk of getting infections

Steroids will be used as little as possible, and at the lowest possible dose, to help avoid side effects.

Make sure you attend any check-ups your doctor recommends so problems can be spotted and treated early.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of bullous pemphigoid

Bullous pemphigoid is caused by a problem with the immune system (the body's defence against infection). Instead of attacking germs, it attacks and damages the skin.

It's not known why this happens. Sometimes it's been linked to skin damage (such as sunburn) or taking certain medicines.

Bullous pemphigoid is not:

  • contagious – it can't be spread to other people
  • caused by an allergy
  • affected by diet or lifestyle
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Body odour (BO):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Body odour (BO)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Body odour (BO)", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Information and advice about how to treat body odour, including when to see a GP if the problem persists.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/body-odour-bo/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-01-10T13:03:00+00:00", "2022-01-10T13:03:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/body-odour-bo/", "name": "Body odour (BO)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-06-21T07:18:54+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/body-odour-bo/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Body odour (BO)"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Body odour is a common problem. You can usually treat it yourself.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How to treat body odour yourself

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • wash your armpits, groin and feet at least twice a day with soap and dry thoroughly
  • shave your armpits regularly
  • use antiperspirants and deodorants
  • change and wash your clothes regularly
  • wear natural fabrics like cotton, wool and silk
  • wear antibacterial socks
"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not eat too much strong smelling or spicy food
  • do not drink too much coffee or alcohol
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You can ask a pharmacist about:

  • stronger antiperspirants
  • armpit or sweat shields to protect your clothing
  • foot powders for sweaty feet
  • soap substitutes that are gentler on your skin
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Find a service", "identifier": "2", "text": "

Find a pharmacy

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if you have body odour and it has not got better after treating it yourself and:

  • it's affecting your self-esteem
  • you notice a change in how it usually smells
  • you suddenly begin to sweat much more than usual
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments from your GP

If you have severe body odour and sweating, your GP may suggest:

  • stronger, prescription antiperspirants
  • injections in your armpits to reduce the amount of sweat
  • surgery to remove the sweat glands

Read more about treating excessive sweating.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of body odour

Things that can make body odour worse include:

  • exercise
  • hot weather
  • hormonal changes
  • being overweight
  • having a condition like diabetes, kidney disease or liver disease
  • certain types of medicine, such as antidepressants

Body odour may also be linked to excessive sweating and smelly feet.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
