Dyspraxia (developmental co-ordination d:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Dyspraxia (developmental co-ordination disorder) in adults", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Dyspraxia (developmental co-ordination disorder) in adults", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out more about dyspraxia, which is a common disorder that affects movement and co-ordination. Read about the symptoms, causes and treatments for dyspraxia, and find out when to get medical help.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/developmental-coordination-disorder-dyspraxia-in-adults/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-01T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-10-01T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/developmental-coordination-disorder-dyspraxia-in-adults/", "name": "Dyspraxia (developmental co-ordination disorder) in adults", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-19T13:50:44+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/developmental-coordination-disorder-dyspraxia-in-adults/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Dyspraxia (developmental co-ordination disorder) in adults"}], "keywords": ["Dyspraxia"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Dyspraxia, also known as developmental co-ordination disorder (DCD), is a common disorder that affects movement and co-ordination.

Dyspraxia does not affect your intelligence. It can affect your co-ordination skills \u2013 such as tasks requiring balance, playing sports or learning to drive a car. Dyspraxia can also affect your fine motor skills, such as writing or using small objects.

This page focuses on dyspraxia in adults.\u00a0You can also read about childhood dyspraxia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms of dyspraxia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of dyspraxia

Symptoms of dyspraxia can vary between individuals and may change over time. You may find routine tasks difficult.

If you have dyspraxia it may affect:

  • your co-ordination, balance and movement
  • how you learn new skills, think, and remember information at work and home
  • your daily living skills, such as dressing or preparing meals
  • your ability to write, type, draw and grasp small objects
  • how you function in social situations
  • how you deal with your emotions
  • time management, planning and personal organisation skills

Dyspraxia should not be confused with other disorders affecting movement, such as cerebral palsy and stroke. It can affect people of all intellectual abilities.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to see a GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see a GP

See a GP\u00a0if you think you may have undiagnosed dyspraxia or problems with your\u00a0co-ordination. It's a good idea to\u00a0keep a diary of your\u00a0symptoms.\u00a0

The GP may refer you to a\u00a0physiotherapist or an occupational therapist\u00a0for tests. They'll assess your movements and how\u00a0your symptoms are\u00a0affecting you before making a diagnosis.\u00a0

If you have\u00a0dyspraxia, you\u00a0may also have other conditions, such as:

  • attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
  • dyslexia
  • autism spectrum disorder
  • difficulty learning or understanding maths (dyscalculia)
  • depression or anxiety
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes of dyspraxia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of dyspraxia

It's not known what causes dyspraxia. You may be at a higher risk of developing it\u00a0if you were born prematurely.

Dyspraxia is more common in men and often runs in families.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment for\u00a0dyspraxia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for\u00a0dyspraxia

There is no cure for dyspraxia but there are therapies\u00a0that can help with daily living, such as:

  • occupational therapy\u00a0\u2013 to\u00a0help you find practical ways to remain independent and manage everyday tasks such as\u00a0writing or preparing food
  • cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)\u00a0\u2013 a talking therapy that\u00a0can help you manage your problems by changing the way you think and behave

It may also help if you:

  • keep fit\u00a0\u2013 you may find regular exercise helps with co-ordination, reduces feelings of fatigue and prevents you gaining weight
  • learn how to use a computer or laptop if writing by hand is difficult
  • use a calendar, diary or app to improve your organisation
  • learn how to talk positively about your challenges and how you've overcome them
  • get support from programmes such as Access to Work from Jobcentre Plus
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Support for people living with dyspraxia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Support for people living with dyspraxia

Dyspraxia can have a big effect on your life, but support is available to help you manage your condition.

It might help to talk to others with dyspraxia or to connect with a charity.

You may find these charity and forum links useful:

  • Dyspraxia Foundation\u00a0\u2013\u00a0it has a list of local support groups you can join to share your experiences with others
  • Dyspraxic Adults\u00a0\u2013 a forum for adults with dyspraxia
  • Movement Matters UK\u00a0\u2013 see\u00a0its page of useful links
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Diabetes:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Diabetes", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Diabetes", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about diabetes, a lifelong condition that causes a person's blood sugar level to become too high.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diabetes/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-07-11T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-07-11T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diabetes/", "name": "Diabetes", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-25T11:40:50+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diabetes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Diabetes"}], "keywords": ["Hyperglycaemia", "Thirst", "Type 1 diabetes", "Type 2 diabetes", "Gestational diabetes", "Weight loss", "Diabetes", "Diabetes clinics", "Diabetic", "Healthy eating", "Insulin"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diabetes is a lifelong condition that causes a person's blood sugar level to become too high.

There are\u00a02 main types of diabetes:

  • type 1 diabetes \u2013 where\u00a0the body's immune system attacks and destroys the cells that produce insulin
  • type 2 diabetes\u00a0\u2013\u00a0where the body does not produce enough insulin, or the body's cells do not react to insulin

Type 2 diabetes is far more common than type 1. In\u00a0the UK,\u00a0around 90% of all adults\u00a0with diabetes have type 2.

During pregnancy, some women have such high levels of blood glucose that their body is unable to\u00a0produce enough insulin to absorb it all. This is known as\u00a0gestational diabetes.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Get the flu vaccine

Flu can be very serious if you have diabetes. Ask for your free flu jab at:

  • your GP surgery
  • a local pharmacy that has a flu vaccine service

Find out more about the flu vaccine

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Advice during the coronavirus outbreak

  • Diabetes UK: updates about coronavirus
  • NHS helpline for adults who use insulin: call 0345 123 2399 (Monday to Friday from 9am to 6pm)
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Pre-diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Pre-diabetes

Many more people have blood sugar levels above the normal range, but not high enough to be diagnosed as having diabetes.

This is sometimes known as pre-diabetes. If\u00a0your blood sugar level is above the normal range, your risk of developing full-blown diabetes is increased.

It's very important for diabetes to be diagnosed as early as possible because it will get progressively worse if left untreated.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to see a doctor", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see a doctor

Visit your GP as soon as possible if you experience the main symptoms of diabetes, which include:

  • feeling very\u00a0thirsty
  • peeing more frequently than usual, particularly at night
  • feeling very tired
  • weight loss and loss of muscle bulk
  • itching around the penis or vagina, or frequent episodes of thrush
  • cuts or wounds that heal slowly
  • blurred vision

Type 1 diabetes can develop quickly over weeks or even days.

Many people have type 2 diabetes for years without realising because the early symptoms tend to be general.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of diabetes

The amount of sugar in the blood is controlled by a hormone called insulin, which is produced by the pancreas (a gland behind the stomach).

When food is digested and enters your bloodstream, insulin moves glucose out of the blood and into cells, where it's broken down to produce energy.

However,\u00a0if you have\u00a0diabetes, your\u00a0body is unable to break down glucose into energy. This is because there's either not enough insulin to move the glucose, or the insulin produced does not work properly.

There are no lifestyle changes you can make to lower your risk of type 1 diabetes.

You can help manage type 2 diabetes through healthy eating, regular exercise and achieving a healthy body weight.

Read about how to reduce your diabetes risk.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Living with diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Living with diabetes

If you're diagnosed with diabetes, you'll need to\u00a0eat healthily, take regular exercise\u00a0and carry out regular blood tests\u00a0to ensure your blood glucose levels stay balanced.

You can use the\u00a0BMI healthy weight calculator to check whether you're a healthy\u00a0weight.

You can find apps and tools to help you manage your diabetes and have a healthier lifestyle in the NHS Apps Library.

People diagnosed with type 1 diabetes also require regular\u00a0insulin injections for the rest of their life.

As type 2 diabetes is a progressive condition, medicine may eventually be required, usually in the form of tablets.

Read about:\u00a0

  • treating type 1 diabetes
  • treating type 2 diabetes
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Diabetic eye screening", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diabetic eye screening

Everyone with diabetes aged 12 or over should be invited to have their eyes screened once a year.

If you have diabetes, your eyes are at risk from diabetic retinopathy, a condition that can lead to sight loss if it's not treated.

Screening, which involves\u00a0a 30-minute check to examine the back of the eyes,\u00a0is a way of detecting the condition early so it can be treated more effectively.

Read more about diabetic eye screening.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}

"name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "
  • Diabetic eye screening is a test to check for eye problems caused by diabetes.
  • Eye problems caused by diabetes are called diabetic retinopathy. This can lead to sight loss if it's not found early.
  • The eye screening test can find problems before they affect your sight.
  • Pictures are taken of the back of your eyes to check for any changes.
  • If you have diabetes and you're aged 12 or over, you'll get a letter asking you to have your eyes checked at least once a year.

Coronavirus update

Diabetic eye screening services are now running.

You may be prioritised if:

  • you're pregnant
  • you've not had a screening test before
  • a previous test has shown you have a higher risk of eye damage

Contact your GP surgery or optician online or by phone if you have diabetes and are worried about your sight.

It\u2019s important to go to your appointment unless you or someone you live with has symptoms of coronavirus. All NHS services are making sure it's safe for you to attend.

Diabetic ketoacidosis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Diabetic ketoacidosis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Diabetic ketoacidosis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a serious complication of diabetes, including why it happens, what the symptoms are and how to prevent it.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diabetic-ketoacidosis/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-05-01T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-05-01T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diabetic-ketoacidosis/", "name": "Diabetic ketoacidosis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-05-11T12:12:34+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/diabetic-ketoacidosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Diabetic ketoacidosis"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious problem that can happen in people with\u00a0diabetes\u00a0if their body starts to run out of insulin.

When this happens, harmful substances called ketones\u00a0build up in the body, which can be life-threatening if it's not found and treated quickly.

DKA mainly affects people with\u00a0type 1 diabetes, but can\u00a0sometimes affect\u00a0people with\u00a0type 2 diabetes.\u00a0If you have diabetes, it's important to be aware of the risk and know what to do if you get DKA.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of diabetic ketoacidosis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of\u00a0DKA include:

  • needing to pee more than usual
  • feeling very\u00a0thirsty
  • being sick
  • tummy\u00a0pain
  • breath that smells fruity (like pear drop sweets, or nail varnish)
  • deep or fast breathing
  • feeling very tired or sleepy
  • confusion
  • passing out

You can get DKA if you have high blood sugar (hyperglycaemia)\u00a0and a high level of ketones in your blood or urine. You can check your ketone levels using a home-testing kit.

Symptoms usually start over a 24-hour period, but they can happen faster.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Check\u00a0your blood sugar and ketone levels", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check your blood sugar level if you have symptoms of DKA.

If your blood sugar level is\u00a011mmol/L or\u00a0above, and you have a blood or urine ketone testing kit, check your ketone level.

If you\u00a0do a blood ketone test:

  • lower than 0.6mmol/L is a normal reading
  • 0.6 to 1.5mmol/L means you're at a slightly increased risk of DKA and you should test again in 2 hours
  • 1.6 to\u00a02.9mmol/L means you're at an increased risk of DKA and should contact your diabetes team or GP as soon as possible
  • 3mmol/L or\u00a0above means you have a very high risk of DKA and should\u00a0get medical help\u00a0immediately

If you do a urine ketone test, a result of more than 2+ means there's a high chance you have DKA and you should get medical help immediately.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When\u00a0to get medical help", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Go to your nearest A&E\u00a0immediately if you think you have DKA, especially if you have a high level of ketones in your blood or urine.

DKA is an emergency and needs to be treated in hospital immediately.

Call your diabetes team or GP\u00a0as soon as possible\u00a0if you're not sure\u00a0whether you need emergency help\u00a0\u2013 for example:

  • your\u00a0blood sugar or ketone levels are high or getting higher over time, but you do not feel unwell
  • you feel unwell but your blood sugar or ketone levels are normal or are only a little bit higher than\u00a0usual

If you cannot contact your care team or GP, call your\u00a0local\u00a0out-of-hours service\u00a0or\u00a0NHS 111\u00a0for advice.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes\u00a0of diabetic ketoacidosis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

DKA is caused by a lack of insulin in the body, which results in the body breaking down fat for energy. Ketones are released into the body as the fat is broken down.

If you have diabetes, certain things can make\u00a0this more likely to happen, including:

  • having an infection,\u00a0such as\u00a0flu\u00a0or a urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • not following your treatment plan, such as missing doses of insulin
  • an injury or surgery
  • taking certain medicines, such as steroids
  • binge drinking
  • using illegal drugs
  • pregnancy
  • having\u00a0your\u00a0period

Sometimes, there's no obvious trigger.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Preventing\u00a0diabetic ketoacidosis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The following tips can help reduce your chances of getting DKA:

  • check your blood sugar level regularly so you can notice and treat an increase quickly\u00a0\u2013 read about\u00a0how to treat high blood sugar on our page about hyperglycaemia
  • follow your treatment plan\u00a0\u2013 do not stop taking insulin unless you're told to by a healthcare professional
  • take extra care when you're ill\u00a0\u2013 your\u00a0diabetes team can\u00a0give you some "sick-day rules" to follow, which include things like checking your blood sugar more often and checking your ketone level
  • be careful taking new medicines\u00a0\u2013 check with a doctor or pharmacist first, as some medicines can increase the risk of DKA

Contact your diabetes team or GP for advice if you find it hard to keep your blood sugar level down.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments\u00a0for diabetic ketoacidosis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

DKA\u00a0is usually treated in hospital.

Treatments for DKA include:

  • insulin, usually\u00a0given\u00a0into a vein (intravenously)
  • fluids given into a vein to rehydrate your body
  • nutrients\u00a0given into a vein to replace any you've lost

You'll also be closely monitored for any life-threatening problems that can happen, such as problems with your brain, kidneys or lungs.

You can leave hospital when you're well enough to eat and drink and tests show a safe level of ketones in your body.\u00a0It's common to stay in hospital for around 2 days.

Before leaving hospital, ask to speak to a diabetes nurse about why you got DKA and what you can do to stop it happening again.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion)", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion), including why it happens and what problems it can cause.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/digeorge-syndrome/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-04-02T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-04-02T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/digeorge-syndrome/", "name": "DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-06T11:03:28+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/digeorge-syndrome/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion)"}], "keywords": ["Genetics/stem cells", "cleft lip and palate", "muscle pain", "Birth defects", "Noonan syndrome", "learning disabilites", "Muscles", "Eye", "Congenital heart diseases", "Children"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

DiGeorge syndrome is a condition present from birth that can cause a range of lifelong problems, including heart defects and learning difficulties.

The severity of the condition varies. Some children can be\u00a0severely ill and very occasionally may die from it, but many others may grow up without realising they have it.

DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a problem with a person's genes, called 22q11 deletion. It is not usually passed on to a child by their parents, but it is in a few cases.

It's often diagnosed soon after birth with a blood test to check for the genetic fault.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of DiGeorge syndrome", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

DiGeorge syndrome can cause a range of problems,\u00a0but\u00a0most people will not have all of these.

Some of the most common\u00a0issues are:

  • learning and behaviour problems\u00a0\u2013 including delays in learning to\u00a0walk or talk,\u00a0learning disabilities and problems such as\u00a0attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or autism
  • speech and hearing problems \u2013 including temporary hearing loss due to frequent ear infections, being slow to start talking and having a "nasal-sounding" voice
  • mouth and feeding problems\u00a0\u2013 including a\u00a0gap in the\u00a0top of the mouth or lip\u00a0(cleft lip\u00a0or\u00a0palate), difficulty feeding and sometimes bringing food back up through the nose
  • heart problems\u00a0\u2013 some children and adults have heart defects from birth (congenital heart disease)
  • hormone problems\u00a0\u2013\u00a0an underactive parathyroid gland (hypoparathyroidism)\u00a0is common and can lead to problems such as shaking (tremors) and\u00a0seizures (fits)

Other possible problems include:

  • a higher risk of getting infections\u00a0\u2013 such as ear infections,\u00a0oral thrush\u00a0and\u00a0chest infections\u00a0\u2013 because the immune system (the body's natural defence against illness) is weaker than normal
  • bone, muscle and joint problems\u00a0\u2013 including leg pains that keep coming back, an unusually curved spine\u00a0(scoliosis)\u00a0and\u00a0rheumatoid arthritis
  • short stature\u00a0\u2013 children and adults may be shorter than average
  • mental health problems\u00a0\u2013 adults are more likely to have problems such as\u00a0schizophrenia and anxiety disorders
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes\u00a0of DiGeorge syndrome", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a problem called 22q11 deletion. This is where a small piece of genetic material is missing from a person's DNA.

In about 9 in 10 cases (90%), the bit of DNA\u00a0was\u00a0missing from the egg or sperm that led to the pregnancy. This can happen by chance when sperm and eggs are made. It is not a result of anything you did before or during the pregnancy.

In these cases, there's usually no family history of DiGeorge syndrome and the risk of it happening again to other children is very small.

In around 1 in 10 cases (10%),\u00a0the 22q11 deletion is passed on to\u00a0a child by\u00a0a parent who has DiGeorge syndrome, although they may not realise they have it if it's mild.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What\u00a0are the chances of my next child having DiGeorge syndrome?", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If neither parent has DiGeorge syndrome, the risk of having another child with it is thought to be less than 1 in 100 (1%).

If 1 parent has the condition, they have a 1 in 2 (50%) chance of passing it on to their child. This applies to\u00a0each pregnancy.

Speak to a GP if\u00a0you're planning a pregnancy and you have a family history of DiGeorge syndrome, or you have a child with it.

They may refer you\u00a0for a genetic test and talk about your\u00a0level of risk and discuss your options. These may include:

  • having a blood test to check if you or your partner carry the genetic problem that causes DiGeorge syndrome
  • having tests during pregnancy (chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis) to check if your\u00a0baby has the genetic problem that causes the condition\u00a0\u2013 although this\u00a0cannot show how severely your child will be affected
  • pre-implantation genetic diagnosis\u00a0\u2013 a type of\u00a0IVF where eggs are fertilised in a laboratory and embryos are tested for genetic problems before they're implanted in the womb (this is not always available on the NHS)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment\u00a0and support for DiGeorge syndrome", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There's currently no cure for DiGeorge syndrome. Children and adults with the condition will be closely monitored to check for problems, and these can be treated as they happen, if needed.

For example, someone with DiGeorge syndrome may have:

  • regular hearing tests, blood tests, heart scans and measurements of their height and weight
  • an assessment of their development and learning ability before starting school\u00a0\u2013 if your child has a learning disability, they may need extra support at a mainstream school, or they may benefit from attending a special school (read more about education for children with learning disabilities)
  • speech therapy to help with speech problems and dietary changes (or sometimes a temporary feeding tube) to help with feeding problems
  • physiotherapy\u00a0for\u00a0problems with strength and movement
  • treatment from a podiatrist for foot and leg problems, and devices such as shoe inserts (orthoses) for leg pain
  • surgery for more severe problems \u2013 for example, surgery to repair heart defects or an operation to repair a cleft palate

You may find it useful to speak to a social worker, psychologist or counsellor, who you can contact directly or\u00a0through a doctor.

Charities such as\u00a0Max Appeal! may also be a good source of support.

Read more advice about\u00a0caring for a disabled child.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Outlook\u00a0for DiGeorge syndrome", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Everyone with DiGeorge syndrome is affected differently and it's difficult to predict how severe the condition will be.\u00a0Most\u00a0children survive into adulthood.

As someone with DiGeorge syndrome gets older, some\u00a0symptoms, such as heart and\u00a0speech problems, tend to become less of an issue. However, behavioural, learning, and mental health problems\u00a0can continue to\u00a0affect their daily life.

Many people with DiGeorge syndrome who reach adulthood will have a relatively normal life span,\u00a0but ongoing health problems can sometimes mean their life expectancy is a bit lower than usual. It's important to\u00a0attend regular check-ups so that any problems\u00a0can be\u00a0found and treated early.

Adults with DiGeorge syndrome are often able to live independently.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Information about you or your child", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If your child has\u00a0DiGeorge syndrome, your clinical team will pass information about them to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

Find out more about the register

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Dislocated kneecap:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Dislocated kneecap", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Dislocated kneecap", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about the symptoms of a dislocated kneecap, what to do and how long it usually takes to recover.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dislocated-kneecap/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-05-20T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-05-20T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dislocated-kneecap/", "name": "Dislocated kneecap", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-05-21T11:36:15+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dislocated-kneecap/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Dislocated kneecap"}], "keywords": ["Knee"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A dislocated kneecap is a common injury that normally takes about 6 weeks to heal.

It's often caused by a blow or a sudden change in direction when the leg is planted on the ground, such as during sports or dancing.

The kneecap (patella) normally sits over the front of the knee. It glides over a groove in the joint when you bend or straighten your leg.

When the kneecap dislocates, it comes out of this groove and the supporting tissues can be stretched or torn.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms of a dislocated kneecap", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of a dislocated kneecap

When a kneecap dislocates, it'll usually look out of place or at an odd angle. But in many cases it'll pop back into place soon afterwards.

Other symptoms can include:

  • a "popping" sensation
  • severe knee pain
  • being unable to straighten the knee
  • sudden swelling of the knee
  • being unable to walk
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What to do if you dislocate your kneecap", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What to do if you dislocate your kneecap

A dislocated kneecap is not usually serious and will often pop back into place by itself.

But it's still a good idea to get it checked by a health professional:

  • if your kneecap has gone back into place by itself – go to your nearest urgent treatment centre or A&E
  • if you cannot get to hospital without being in severe pain, you should call an ambulance – do not try to put the cap back in place yourself

While you're on your way to hospital or waiting for an ambulance, sit still with your leg in the most comfortable position.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatment for a dislocated kneecap", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for a dislocated kneecap

If your kneecap has not corrected itself by the time you get to hospital, a doctor will manipulate it back into place. This is known as a reduction.

You may be given medicine to ensure you're relaxed and free from pain while this is done.

Once the kneecap is back in place, you may have an X-ray to check the bones are in the correct position and there's no other damage.

You'll be sent home with painkillers and your leg will normally be immobilised in a removable splint to begin with.

A few weeks of physiotherapy will be recommended to aid your recovery.

Surgery is usually only necessary if there was a fracture or another associated injury, such as a ligament tear.

It may also be done if you have dislocated your kneecap at least once before.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Recovering from a dislocated kneecap", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from a dislocated kneecap

Your knee may hurt at first and you'll probably need to take painkillers, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen. See a GP if this does not control the pain.

During the first few days, you can help reduce any swelling by keeping your leg elevated when sitting and holding an ice pack to your knee for 10 to 15 minutes every few hours.

A physiotherapist will teach you some exercises to do at home to strengthen the muscles that stabilise your kneecap and improve the movement of your knee.

The splint should only be kept on for comfort and should be removed to do these exercises as soon as you're able to move your leg.

It usually takes about 6 weeks to fully recover from a dislocated kneecap, although sometimes it can take a bit longer to return to sports or other strenuous activities.

Ask your GP, consultant or physiotherapist for advice about returning to your normal activities.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "If you keep dislocating your kneecap", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you keep dislocating your kneecap

Most people who dislocate their kneecap will not dislocate it again. But in some people it can keep happening.

This often happens if the tissues that support the kneecap are weak or loose, such as in people with hypermobile joints, or because the groove in the bone beneath the kneecap is too shallow or uneven.

Regularly doing the exercises your physiotherapist recommends can help strengthen the tissues that hold the kneecap in place and reduce the risk of dislocating it again.

Surgery may occasionally be needed if the kneecap keeps dislocating. A common procedure is a medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) repair.

This is where the connective tissue (ligament) that helps hold the kneecap in place is repaired and strengthened.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Dislocated shoulder:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Dislocated shoulder", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Dislocated shoulder", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about dislocated shoulder, including how a dislocation happens, how to tell if your shoulder is dislocated, what to do, plus treatment and recovery.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dislocated-shoulder/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-01-21T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-01-21T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dislocated-shoulder/", "name": "Dislocated shoulder", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-01-23T17:42:37+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dislocated-shoulder/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Dislocated shoulder"}], "keywords": ["Shoulder"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A dislocated shoulder happens when your upper arm pops out of your shoulder socket.

The shoulder is one of the easiest joints to dislocate because the ball joint of your upper arm sits in a very shallow socket.

This makes the arm extremely mobile and able to move in many directions, but also means it is not very stable.

In some cases, the surrounding tissues supporting the shoulder joint may also be overstretched or torn.

A dislocated shoulder takes between 12 and 16 weeks to heal after the shoulder has been put back into place.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How a dislocated shoulder happens", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How a dislocated shoulder happens

You can dislocate your shoulder if you fall on to your arm\u00a0heavily. Most people dislocate their shoulder while playing a contact sport, such as rugby, or in a sports-related accident.

In older people, the cause is often\u00a0falling on to outstretched hands\u00a0\u2013 for example, after slipping on ice.

Shoulder dislocations can happen more easily in people who are highly flexible, such as those with loose joints\u00a0(joint hypermobility).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Have I dislocated my shoulder?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Have I dislocated my shoulder?

In most cases of dislocated shoulder, the ball part of the joint pops out in front of the shoulder socket.

This is usually obvious because:

  • you will not be able to move your arm and it will be very painful
  • your shoulder will suddenly look square rather than round
  • you may be able to see a lump or bulge (the top of the arm bone) under the skin in front of your shoulder

It's much more unusual for the bone to pop out of the back of the shoulder joint.\u00a0This can happen after an epileptic fit or an electrocution injury, and is less easy to spot.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What to do with a dislocated shoulder", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What to do with a dislocated shoulder

Go to\u00a0your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department immediately if you think you've dislocated your shoulder.

Do not try to pop your arm back in yourself\u00a0\u2013 you could damage the tissues, nerves and blood vessels around the shoulder joint.

While waiting for medical help,\u00a0avoid moving\u00a0your upper arm as much as possible.

Place something soft, such as a folded blanket or pillow, in the gap between your arm and the side of your chest to support it.

If you can, ask someone to make a simple sling to hold your lower arm across your chest, with the elbow bent at a right angle.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How a dislocated shoulder is treated", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How a dislocated shoulder is treated

You'll be assessed and examined when you get to A&E. You'll usually have an\u00a0X-ray\u00a0to check whether you've broken any bones and confirm the dislocation.

If you have a fracture, you may have further scans to investigate the area in more detail. Fractures with a shoulder dislocation require specialist orthopaedic care, and you may need surgery.

If you do not have any fractures, your arm will be gently manipulated back into its shoulder joint using a procedure known as reduction.

Reduction

You'll be given painkillers and may be offered medicine to help you relax (a sedative).

Reduction is usually carried out in A&E, but sometimes it's done in the operating theatre under\u00a0general anaesthetic (where you're unconscious) by the orthopaedic team.

While you're sitting on the bed, the doctor will rotate your arm around the shoulder joint until it goes back in its socket. This may take a few minutes.

You'll usually have another X-ray to check your shoulder is in the correct position once your shoulder joint is back in place.

Repairing tears in the shoulder tissues

Some people tear ligaments, tendons and other tissues\u00a0when they dislocate their shoulder.

If these tissues have been damaged, you may need surgery to repair them. This can significantly reduce\u00a0the chance of dislocating the same shoulder again in the future for some people.

Surgery to repair shoulder tissues is done under general anaesthetic. It's often done using keyhole surgery, where small cuts (incisions) and\u00a0a thin tube with a light and camera at one end (arthroscope) are used.

Sometimes it's necessary to have open surgery to move bones around in the shoulder to prevent further dislocations.

Surgery can sometimes be avoided by doing appropriate exercises to strengthen the shoulder\u00a0if the tissues are overstretched but not torn.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovering from a dislocated shoulder", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from a dislocated shoulder

You can usually go home soon after your shoulder is put back in place, but you'll need to rest your arm in a sling for a few days while the pain settles.

You may need to return to hospital for follow-up care, and may also be referred for\u00a0physiotherapy\u00a0to rehabilitate and strengthen your shoulder.

Arm and shoulder exercises

Some gentle arm and shoulder exercises may be recommended for you to do at home with your arm out of its sling.

These will help:

  • reduce stiffness
  • relieve some of the pain
  • build up strength in your shoulder muscles

It's likely you'll feel some aching, discomfort or stretching when doing these exercises. However, if you experience intense pain for more than 30 minutes, do the exercise\u00a0less forcefully and less often.

Pain relief

Your shoulder may be\u00a0very painful during the first few days at home and you may need to take painkillers, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen. Always follow the dosage instructions on the packet.

If\u00a0this does not control the pain, your GP can prescribe a stronger painkiller,\u00a0such as codeine. The pain should settle fairly quickly once the sling is removed and you start to move your shoulder.

Recovery time

You can stop wearing the sling after a few days, but it takes about 12 to 16 weeks to completely recover from a dislocated shoulder.

You'll usually be able to resume most activities within 2 weeks, but should avoid heavy lifting and sports involving shoulder movements for\u00a0between 6 weeks\u00a0and 3 months. Your\u00a0care team\u00a0will advise you.

You'll probably be off work for 2 to 4 weeks, or longer, if you have a physical job. Discuss this with your care team.

If you've also broken your arm or shoulder joint, you may need to wear your sling for up to 6 weeks and recovery will take longer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Dislocating your shoulder again", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Dislocating your shoulder again

The chances of dislocating your shoulder again will depend on your age and how well the tissues surrounding the joint healed the first time.

It can help if any torn tissues were surgically repaired after the dislocated shoulder was put back in place.

However, subsequent dislocations do sometimes occur, particularly in people younger than\u00a025 and those over 40.

Doing regular recovery exercises under the supervision of a physiotherapist\u00a0and avoiding awkward arm positions can also reduce the risk of dislocating your shoulder again.
