"genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dyslexia/", "name": "Dyslexia", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2018-10-10T13:49:31+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dyslexia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Dyslexia", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dyslexia/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dyslexia/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dyslexia/living-with/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Management"}], "keywords": ["Brain", "Dyslexia"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Dyslexia is a common learning difficulty that can cause problems with reading, writing and spelling.

It's a specific learning difficulty, which means it causes problems with certain abilities used for learning, such as reading and writing.

Unlike a learning disability, intelligence isn't affected.

It's estimated up to 1 in every 10 people in the UK has some degree of dyslexia.

Dyslexia is a lifelong problem that can present challenges on a daily basis, but support is available to improve reading and writing skills and help those with the problem be successful at school and work.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What are the signs of dyslexia?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What are the signs of dyslexia?

Signs of dyslexia usually become apparent when a child starts school and begins to focus more on learning how to read and write.

A person with dyslexia may:

  • read and write very slowly
  • confuse the order of letters in words
  • put letters the wrong way round (such as writing "b" instead of "d")
  • have poor or inconsistent spelling
  • understand information when told verbally, but have difficulty with information that's written down
  • find it hard to carry out a sequence of directions
  • struggle with planning and organisation

But people with dyslexia often have good skills in other areas, such as creative thinking and problem solving.

Read more about the symptoms of dyslexia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Getting help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Getting help

If you think your child may have dyslexia, the first step is to speak to their teacher or their school's special educational needs co-ordinator (SENCO) about your concerns.

They may be able to offer additional support to help your child if necessary.

If your child continues to have problems despite extra support, you or the school may want to consider requesting a more in-depth assessment from a specialist dyslexia teacher or an educational psychologist.

This can be arranged through the school, or you can request a private assessment by contacting:

  • an educational psychologist directly (you can find a directory of chartered psychologists on the British Psychological Society's website)
  • a voluntary organisation that can arrange an assessment, such as a local dyslexia association

Adults who wish to be assessed for dyslexia should contact a local or national dyslexia association for advice.

Read more about how dyslexia is diagnosed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Support for people with dyslexia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Support for people with dyslexia

If your child has dyslexia, they'll probably need extra educational support from their school.

With appropriate support, there's usually no reason your child can't go to a mainstream school, although a small number of children may benefit from attending a specialist school.

Techniques and support that may help your child include:

  • occasional 1-to-1 teaching or lessons in a small group with a specialist teacher
  • phonics (a special learning technique that focuses on improving the ability to identify and process the smaller sounds that make up words)
  • technology like computers and speech recognition software that may make it easier for your child to read and write when they're a bit older

Universities also have specialist staff who can support young people with dyslexia in higher education.

Technology such as word processors and electronic organisers can be useful for adults, too.

Employers are required to make reasonable adjustments to the workplace to help people with dyslexia, such as allowing extra time for certain tasks.

Read more about how dyslexia is managed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Support groups", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Support groups

As well as national dyslexia charities such as the British Dyslexia Association (BDA), there are several local dyslexia associations (LDAs).

These are independently registered charities that run workshops and help to provide local support and access to information.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What causes dyslexia?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes dyslexia?

People with dyslexia find it difficult to recognise the different sounds that make up words and relate these to letters. 

Dyslexia isn't related to a person's general level of intelligence. Children and adults of all intellectual abilities can be affected by dyslexia.

The exact cause of dyslexia is unknown, but it often appears to run in families.

It's thought certain genes inherited from your parents may act together in a way that affects how some parts of the brain develop during early life.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Dystonia:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Dystonia", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Dystonia", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Dystonia is a medical term for a range of movement disorders that cause muscle spasms and contractions. The spasms and contractions may either be sustained or may come and go.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dystonia/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-03-23T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-03-23T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dystonia/", "name": "Dystonia", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2018-12-10T14:51:51+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/dystonia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Dystonia"}], "keywords": ["Neurological (nerve and brain) diseases", "Dystonia"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Dystonia is the name for uncontrolled and sometimes painful muscle movements (spasms). It's usually a lifelong problem, but treatment can help relieve the symptoms.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if you have dystonia

Dystonia can affect your whole body or just 1 part. It can start at any age.

Symptoms of dystonia include:

  • uncontrolled muscle cramps and spasms
  • parts of your body twisting into unusual positions – such as your neck being twisted to the side or your feet turning inwards
  • shaking (tremors)
  • uncontrolled blinking

The symptoms may be continuous or come and go. They may be triggered by things like stress or certain activities.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "What can trigger dystonia symptoms", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "
  • tiredness
  • stress
  • drinking alcohol or caffeine
  • talking
  • eating or chewing
  • activities like writing, typing or playing an instrument
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if you think you might have dystonia

Dystonia is uncommon, but it's best to get the symptoms checked out.

If your GP thinks you could have dystonia, they may refer you to a specialist called a neurologist for tests.

"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How dystonia is diagnosed

To diagnose dystonia, a neurologist may:

  • ask about your symptoms
  • ask about any other conditions you have and if anyone else in your family has dystonia (sometimes it can be inherited)
  • carry out some blood and urine tests
  • arrange a brain scan to look for any problems

If you're diagnosed with dystonia, your neurologist can tell you which type you have and what your treatment options are.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "Main types of dystonia", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Type Area affected
Generalised dystonia most of the body
Myocolonus dystonia arms, neck and torso
Cervical dystonia (torticollis) neck only
Blepharospasm eyes
Laryngeal dystonia voice box (larynx)
Task-specific dystonia (writer's cramp) arms and wrists
Oromandibular dystonia lower face, tongue or jaw
"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The Dystonia Society has more on the different types of dystonia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments for dystonia

Treatment can help relieve the symptoms of dystonia. The best option for you depends on the type of dystonia you have.

The main treatments for dystonia are:

  • injections of a medicine called botulinum toxin directly into the affected muscles – these need to be repeated about every 3 months
  • medicine to relax the muscles in a larger part of your body – given as tablets or injections into a vein
  • a type of surgery called deep brain stimulation

Physiotherapy and occupational therapy may also help.

Surgery for dystonia

Deep brain stimulation is the main type of surgery for dystonia. It may be offered on the NHS if other treatments don't help.

It involves inserting a small device, similar to a pacemaker, under the skin of your chest or tummy.

The device sends electrical signals along wires placed in the part of the brain that controls movement.

The Dystonia Society has more on deep brain stimulation.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Living with it", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Living with dystonia

Dystonia affects people in different ways. The severity of symptoms can vary from one day to another.

It can have a big effect on your life and make daily activities painful and difficult.

It's usually a lifelong condition. It may get worse for a few years but then remain steady. Occasionally, it can improve over time.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

You can get support and advice about living with dystonia from The Dystonia Society.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of dystonia

Dystonia is thought to be caused by a problem with the part of the brain that controls movement.

Often the cause is unknown.

Sometimes it can be due to:

  • an inherited genetic problem
  • Parkinson's disease
  • a stroke
  • cerebral palsy
  • multiple sclerosis
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}

"Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/frontotemporal-dementia/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Dementia", "Long-term management", "Care homes", "Care in own home", "Care away from home", "Nursing homes", "Older people", "Brain", "Alzheimer's disease"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Frontotemporal dementia is an uncommon type of dementia that causes problems with behaviour and language.

Dementia is the name for problems with mental abilities caused by gradual changes and damage in the brain.

Frontotemporal dementia affects the front and sides of the brain (the frontal and temporal lobes).

Dementia\u00a0mostly affects people over 65, but frontotemporal dementia tends to start at a younger age.\u00a0Most cases are diagnosed in people aged 45-65, although it\u00a0can also affect younger or older people.

Like other\u00a0types of dementia,\u00a0frontotemporal dementia\u00a0tends to develop slowly and get gradually worse over several years.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and dementia:

  • Alzheimer's Society: Coronavirus information for people affected by dementia
  • Dementia UK: Coronavirus questions and answers
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of frontotemporal dementia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of frontotemporal dementia

Signs of frontotemporal dementia can include:

  • personality and behaviour changes \u2013 acting inappropriately or impulsively, appearing selfish or unsympathetic, neglecting personal hygiene, overeating, or loss of motivation
  • language problems \u2013 speaking slowly, struggling to make the right sounds when saying a word, getting words in the wrong order, or using words incorrectly
  • problems with mental abilities \u2013 getting distracted easily, struggling with planning and organisation
  • memory problems \u2013 these only tend to occur later on, unlike more common forms of dementia, such as\u00a0Alzheimer's disease

There may also be physical problems, such as slow or stiff movements, loss of bladder or bowel control (usually not until later on), muscle weakness or\u00a0difficulty swallowing.

These problems can make daily activities increasingly difficult, and\u00a0the person may eventually be unable to look after themselves.

Read more about the symptoms of frontotemporal dementia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Getting\u00a0medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Getting\u00a0medical advice

See a GP if you think you have early symptoms of dementia. If you're worried about\u00a0someone else, encourage them to make an appointment with a GP and perhaps suggest you go with them.

The GP\u00a0can do some simple checks to try to find the cause of your symptoms,\u00a0and\u00a0they can\u00a0refer you to a\u00a0memory\u00a0clinic or another specialist for further tests\u00a0if needed.

Read more about getting a dementia diagnosis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Tests\u00a0for frontotemporal dementia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Tests\u00a0for frontotemporal dementia

There's no single test for frontotemporal dementia.

The following may be needed to make a diagnosis:

  • an assessment of symptoms \u2013 it's normally helpful to have somebody who knows the person well to give an account of their symptoms, especially as someone with frontotemporal dementia may not be aware of changes in their behaviour
  • an assessment of mental abilities \u2013 this will usually involve a number of tasks and questions
  • blood tests\u00a0\u2013 to rule out conditions with similar symptoms
  • brain scans \u2013\u00a0such as an\u00a0MRI scan, a\u00a0CT scan or a\u00a0PET scan; these can detect signs of dementia and help identify which parts of the brain are most affected, or\u00a0help rule out other problems with the brain
  • lumbar puncture\u00a0\u2013 to test the spinal fluid (fluid that surrounds and supports the brain and spine); this may be useful to rule out Alzheimer's disease as the cause of symptoms

Read more about the tests used to diagnose dementia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for frontotemporal dementia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for frontotemporal dementia

There's currently\u00a0no cure for frontotemporal dementia or any treatment that will slow it down.

But there are treatments that can help control some of the symptoms, possibly for several years.

Treatments include:

  • medicines \u2013 to control some of the behavioural problems
  • therapies \u2013 such as physiotherapy, occupational therapy, and speech and language\u00a0therapy for problems with movement, everyday tasks and communication
  • dementia activities\u00a0\u2013\u00a0such as\u00a0memory cafes, which are drop-in sessions\u00a0for people with memory problems and their carers to get support and advice
  • support groups \u2013\u00a0who can offer tips on managing symptoms from dementia experts and people living with frontotemporal dementia, and their families

Read more about how frontotemporal dementia is treated.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook\u00a0for frontotemporal dementia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook\u00a0for frontotemporal dementia

How quickly frontotemporal dementia gets worse\u00a0varies from person to person and is very difficult to predict.

People with the condition can become socially isolated as the illness progresses. They may not want to spend time in the company of others, or\u00a0may behave in rude or insulting ways.

Home-based help\u00a0will usually be needed at some stage, and some people will eventually need care in a nursing home.

The average survival time after symptoms start is around 8 to 10 years. But this is highly variable and some people live much longer than this.

If you or a loved one has been diagnosed with dementia, remember you're not alone. The NHS and social services,\u00a0as well as voluntary organisations and specialist support groups, can provide advice and support for you and your family.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of frontotemporal dementia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of frontotemporal dementia

Frontotemporal dementia is caused by clumps of abnormal protein forming inside brain cells. These are thought to damage the cells and stop them working properly.

The proteins mainly build up in the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain at the front and sides. These are important\u00a0for controlling language, behaviour, and the ability to plan and organise.

It's not fully understood why this happens, but there's often a genetic link. Around 1 in 8 people who get frontotemporal dementia will have relatives who were also affected by the condition.

If you have a family history of frontotemporal dementia, you may want to consider talking to your doctor about being referred to a geneticist and possibly having a\u00a0genetic test to see if you're at risk.

There's a lot of research being done to try to improve understanding of the causes of frontotemporal dementia so treatments can be discovered.

If you're interested in helping with research, you can speak to a doctor or register your interest on Join Dementia Research.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Other\u00a0names for frontotemporal dementia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Other\u00a0names for frontotemporal dementia

Doctors sometimes use different names to describe frontotemporal dementia. These include:

  • FTD
  • Pick's disease
  • frontal dementia
  • frontotemporal lobar degeneration
  • behavioural variant frontotemporal dementia
  • primary progressive aphasia
  • semantic dementia
  • progressive non-fluent aphasia
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 10, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "More information", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gestational diabetes:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Gestational diabetes", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Gestational diabetes", "alternateName": ["Diabetes in pregnancy"]}, "description": "Find out what gestational diabetes is, what problems it can cause, how it's diagnosed, and what the treatments are.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gestational-diabetes/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-08-06T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-08-06T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gestational-diabetes/", "name": "Gestational diabetes", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-05-05T14:56:06+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gestational-diabetes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Gestational diabetes", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gestational-diabetes/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Gestational diabetes", "Diabetes"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gestational diabetes is high blood sugar\u00a0(glucose) that develops during pregnancy and usually disappears after giving birth.

It can happen at any stage of pregnancy, but is more common in the second or third trimester.

It happens when your body cannot produce enough insulin\u00a0\u2013 a hormone that helps control blood sugar levels\u00a0\u2013\u00a0to meet your extra needs in pregnancy.

Gestational diabetes can cause problems for you and your baby during pregnancy and after birth. But the risks can be reduced if the condition is detected early and well managed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who's\u00a0at risk of gestational diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who's\u00a0at risk of gestational diabetes

Any woman can develop gestational diabetes during pregnancy, but you're at an increased risk if:

  • your\u00a0body mass index (BMI) is above 30 \u2013 use the healthy weight calculator to work out your BMI
  • you previously had a baby who weighed 4.5kg (10lb) or more at birth
  • you had gestational diabetes in a previous pregnancy
  • 1 of your parents or siblings has diabetes
  • you are of south Asian, Black, African-Caribbean or Middle Eastern origin (even if you were born in the UK)

If any of these apply to you, you should be offered\u00a0screening for gestational diabetes\u00a0during your pregnancy.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of gestational diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of gestational diabetes

Gestational diabetes does not usually cause any symptoms.

Most cases are only discovered when your blood sugar levels are tested during\u00a0screening for gestational diabetes.

Some\u00a0women may develop\u00a0symptoms if their blood sugar levels gets too high\u00a0(hyperglycaemia),\u00a0such as:

  • increased\u00a0thirst
  • needing to pee more often than usual
  • a dry mouth
  • tiredness

But some of these symptoms are common during pregnancy and are not necessarily a sign of gestational diabetes. Speak to your midwife or doctor if you're worried about any symptoms you're experiencing.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How\u00a0gestational diabetes can affect your pregnancy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How\u00a0gestational diabetes can affect your pregnancy

Most women with gestational diabetes have otherwise normal pregnancies with healthy babies.

However, gestational diabetes can cause problems such as:

  • your baby growing larger than usual \u2013 this may lead to difficulties during the delivery and increases the likelihood of needing\u00a0induced labour or a caesarean section
  • polyhydramnios \u2013 too much amniotic fluid (the fluid that surrounds the baby) in the womb, which can cause premature labour or problems at delivery
  • premature birth\u00a0\u2013\u00a0giving birth before the 37th week\u00a0of pregnancy
  • pre-eclampsia\u00a0\u2013 a condition that causes high blood pressure during pregnancy and can lead to pregnancy complications if not treated
  • your baby developing\u00a0low blood sugar or\u00a0yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice) after he or she is born, which may require treatment in hospital
  • the loss of your baby (stillbirth) \u2013 though this is rare

Having gestational diabetes also means you're at an increased risk of developing\u00a0type 2 diabetes in the future.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Screening\u00a0for gestational diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Screening\u00a0for gestational diabetes

During your first antenatal appointment (also called a booking appointment) at around week 8 to 12 of your pregnancy, your midwife or doctor will ask you some questions to determine whether you're at an increased risk of gestational diabetes.

If you have 1 or more risk factors for gestational diabetes\u00a0you should be offered a screening test.

The screening test is called an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), which takes about 2 hours.

It involves having a\u00a0blood test in the morning, when you have not had any food or drink for 8 to 10 hours (though you can usually drink water, but check with the hospital if you're unsure).\u00a0You're then given a glucose drink.\u00a0

After resting for 2 hours, another blood sample is taken\u00a0to see how your body is dealing with the glucose.

The OGTT is done when you're between 24 and 28 weeks pregnant.\u00a0If you've had gestational diabetes before, you'll be offered an OGTT earlier in your pregnancy, soon after your booking appointment, then another OGTT at 24 to 28 weeks if the first test is normal.

Find out more about an OGTT.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for gestational diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for gestational diabetes

If you have gestational diabetes, the chances of having problems with your pregnancy can be reduced by controlling your blood sugar levels.

You'll be given a blood sugar testing kit so you can monitor the effects of treatment.

Blood sugar levels may be reduced by changing your diet and exercise routine.\u00a0However, if these changes don't lower your blood sugar levels enough, you will need to take medicine as well. This may be tablets or insulin injections.

You'll also be more closely monitored during your pregnancy and birth to check for any potential problems.

If you have gestational diabetes, it's best to give birth before 41 weeks. Induction of labour or a caesarean section may be recommended if labour does not start naturally by this time.

Earlier delivery may be recommended if there are concerns about your or your baby's health or if your blood sugar levels have not been well controlled.

Find out more about\u00a0how gestational diabetes is treated.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Long-term\u00a0effects of gestational diabetes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Long-term\u00a0effects of gestational diabetes

Gestational diabetes normally goes away after birth. But women who've had it are more likely to develop:

  • gestational diabetes again in future pregnancies
  • type 2 diabetes\u00a0\u2013 a lifelong type of diabetes

You should have a blood test to check for diabetes 6 to 13 weeks after giving birth, and once every year after that if the result is normal.

See your GP if you develop symptoms of high blood sugar, such as increased thirst, needing to pee more often than usual, and\u00a0a dry mouth \u2013 do not wait until your next test.\u00a0

You should have the tests even if you feel well, as many people with diabetes do not have any symptoms.

You'll also be advised about things you can do to reduce your risk of getting diabetes, such as maintaining a healthy weight, eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly.

Some research has suggested that babies of mothers who had gestational diabetes may be more likely to develop diabetes or become obese later in life.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Planning\u00a0future pregnancies", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Planning\u00a0future pregnancies

If you've had gestational diabetes before and you're planning to get pregnant, make sure you get checked for diabetes. Your GP can arrange this.

If you do have diabetes, you should be referred to a diabetes pre-conception clinic for support to ensure your condition is well controlled before you get pregnant.

Read more about diabetes in pregnancy.

If you have an unplanned pregnancy, talk to your GP and tell them you had gestational diabetes in your previous pregnancy.

If tests show you do not have diabetes, you'll be offered screening earlier in pregnancy (soon after your first midwife appointment) and another test at 24 to 28 weeks if the first test is normal.

Alternatively, your midwife or doctor may suggest you test your blood sugar levels yourself using a finger-pricking device in the same way as you did during your previous gestational diabetes.

Hearing loss:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hearing loss", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Hearing loss", "alternateName": ["Deafness"]}, "description": "Find out about the signs of hearing loss and deafness, what can cause it, when to get medical help and what the main treatments are.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-08-01T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-08-01T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/", "name": "Hearing loss", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-10T14:54:28+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Hearing loss", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Hearing loss can be temporary or permanent. It\u00a0often comes on gradually as you get older, but it can sometimes\u00a0happen suddenly.

See a GP if you\u00a0notice any problems with your hearing so you can find out the cause and get advice on treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Signs\u00a0and symptoms of hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Signs\u00a0and symptoms of hearing loss

It's not always easy to tell if you're losing your hearing.

Common signs include:

  • difficulty hearing other people clearly, and misunderstanding what they say, especially in\u00a0noisy places
  • asking people to repeat themselves
  • listening to music or watching television loudly
  • having to concentrate hard to hear what other people are saying, which can be tiring or stressful

The signs can be slightly different if you only\u00a0have hearing loss in 1 ear or if a young child has hearing loss.

Read more about the\u00a0signs and symptoms of hearing loss.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to\u00a0get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to\u00a0get medical help

A GP can help\u00a0if you think you're losing your hearing.

  • if you or your child suddenly lose hearing (in 1 or both ears), call a GP or NHS 111\u00a0as soon as possible
  • if you think your or your child's hearing is getting\u00a0gradually worse, make an appointment to see a GP
  • if you're concerned\u00a0about a\u00a0friend's or family member's hearing, encourage them to see a GP

The GP will ask about your symptoms and look inside your ears\u00a0using a small handheld torch with a magnifying lens. They can also do some simple checks of your hearing.

If needed, they can refer you to a specialist for more hearing tests.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of hearing loss

Hearing loss can have many different causes. For example:

  • sudden hearing loss in 1 ear may be\u00a0due to\u00a0earwax, an\u00a0ear infection, a\u00a0perforated (burst) eardrum\u00a0or\u00a0M\u00e9ni\u00e8re's disease
  • sudden hearing loss in both ears\u00a0may be\u00a0due to damage from a very loud noise, or taking certain medicines that can\u00a0affect hearing
  • gradual hearing loss in 1 ear\u00a0may be due to something inside the ear, such as fluid (glue ear),\u00a0a\u00a0bony growth\u00a0(otosclerosis) or a\u00a0build-up of\u00a0skin cells (cholesteatoma)
  • gradual hearing loss in both ears is usually caused by\u00a0ageing or exposure to loud noises over many years

This may give you an idea of\u00a0the reason for\u00a0hearing loss \u2013\u00a0but make sure you see\u00a0a GP to get a proper diagnosis. It might not always be possible to identify an obvious cause.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for hearing loss

Hearing loss sometimes gets\u00a0better on its own, or may be treated with medicine or a simple procedure. For example, earwax can be sucked out, or\u00a0softened with eardrops.

But other types\u00a0\u2013 such as gradual hearing loss, which\u00a0often happens as you get older \u2013\u00a0may be permanent. In these cases, treatment\u00a0can help make the most of the remaining hearing. This may involve using:

  • hearing aids\u00a0\u2013 several different types are available on the NHS or privately
  • implants\u00a0\u2013 devices that are attached to\u00a0your skull or placed deep inside your ear, if hearing aids are not suitable
  • different ways of\u00a0communicating\u00a0\u2013 such as sign language\u00a0or lip reading

Read more about treatments for\u00a0hearing loss

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Preventing\u00a0hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing\u00a0hearing loss

It's not always possible to prevent hearing loss, but there are some simple things you can do to reduce the risk of damaging your hearing.

These include:

  • not\u00a0having your television, radio or music on too loud
  • using headphones that block out more outside noise, instead of turning up the volume
  • wearing\u00a0ear protection (such as ear defenders) if you work in a noisy environment, such as a\u00a0garage workshop or\u00a0a building site; special vented earplugs that allow some noise in are also available for musicians
  • using ear protection at loud concerts and other events where there are high noise levels
  • not\u00a0inserting objects into your or your children's ears\u00a0\u2013 this includes fingers, cotton buds, cotton wool and tissues

Read more tips to protect your hearing

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Social care and support guide

If you:

  • need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability
  • care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled \u2013 including family members

Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support.

"text": "

Restricted growth, sometimes known as dwarfism, is a condition characterised by unusually short height.

There are 2 main types of restricted growth:

  • proportionate short stature (PSS) – a general lack of growth in the body, arms and legs
  • disproportionate short stature (DSS) – where the arms and legs are particularly short

As well as being short, some people with restricted growth also have other physical problems, such as bowed legs or an unusually curved spine.

But most people don't have any other serious problems and are able to live a relatively normal life, with a normal life expectancy.

Read more about the symptoms of restricted growth.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What causes restricted growth?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes restricted growth?

Causes of PSS

The most common cause of PSS is being born to small parents, but it's sometimes the result of the body not producing enough growth hormone.

Certain genetic syndromes, such as Turner syndrome, Noonan syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome, can also cause PSS.

Causes of DSS

A rare genetic condition called achondroplasia is the most common cause of DSS.

It causes poor bone growth, resulting in short upper arms and thighs.

It doesn't always run in the family – many children with achondroplasia have parents of normal height.

The Restricted Growth Association UK has more information about achondroplasia and other rare types of restricted growth.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Diagnosing restricted growth", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing restricted growth

Restricted growth may be diagnosed before a child is born, soon afterwards, or when growth problems become more obvious as they get older.

Growth hormone deficiency is usually diagnosed using growth hormone stimulation tests.

Medicine is injected into a vein or muscle to cause an increase in growth hormone levels in the blood. A lower than normal level indicates a deficiency in growth hormone.

A brain scan will be needed to look at the pituitary gland (which produces growth hormone) if blood tests show low levels of growth hormone.

If one or both parents have a family history of a condition that causes short stature, their baby can be tested for this during pregnancy (prenatal diagnosis).

Read more about screening tests in pregnancy.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatment for restricted growth", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for restricted growth

Treatment with growth hormone injections may benefit some people with restricted growth and can help a child with the condition grow more than they otherwise would.

In cases of DSS where the legs are particularly short, a leg-lengthening procedure is sometimes used, but there's some uncertainty about its safety and effectiveness.

Read more about treatments for restricted growth.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Detached retina (retinal detachment)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Detached retina (retinal detachment)", "alternateName": ["Retinal detachment"]}, "description": "Read about a detached retina, which is where the thin layer at the back of the eye (retina) becomes loose from the back of the eye. Find out what the symptoms are, what causes it and how it's treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/detached-retina-retinal-detachment/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-12-16T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-12-16T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/detached-retina-retinal-detachment/", "name": "Detached retina (retinal detachment)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-12-30T16:44:07+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/detached-retina-retinal-detachment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Detached retina (retinal detachment)"}], "keywords": ["Retinal detachment", "Eye", "DVLA"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A detached retina is when the thin layer at the back of your eye (retina) becomes loose. It needs to be treated quickly to stop it permanently affecting your sight.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Get advice from 111 now if:

  • dots or lines (floaters) suddenly appear in your vision or suddenly increase in number
  • you get flashes of light in your vision
  • you have a dark "curtain" or shadow moving across your vision
  • your vision gets suddenly blurred

These could be symptoms of a detached retina.

111 will tell you what to do. They can tell you the right place to get help if you need to see someone.

Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

Other ways to get help

Get an urgent optician appointment

You can get your eyes checked at an optician.

Call an optician near you and ask if you can have an urgent appointment.

Find an optician

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for a detached retina

You'll be referred to hospital for surgery if tests show your retina may be detached or has started to come away (retinal tear).

This will usually stop your vision getting worse.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "What happens during surgery for a detached retina or tear", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Surgery to re-attach the retina or fix a retinal tear may involve:

  • removing and replacing the jelly inside your eye (vitrectomy)
  • attaching a small band around your eye to push the wall of your eye and retina closer together (scleral buckling)
  • injecting a bubble of gas into your eye to push the retina against the back of your eye (pneumatic retinopexy)
  • sealing the tear in your retina with laser or freezing treatment (cryotherapy)

It's usually done with local anaesthetic, so you're awake but your eye is numbed. You do not normally need to stay in hospital overnight.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovery time after surgery varies. But as a general guide, for 2 to 6 weeks after surgery:

  • your vision may be blurry
  • your eye may be sore and red – take paracetamol if you need to
  • you may need to take time off work
  • you may not be able to drive
  • you may need to avoid flying (if you've had a bubble of gas put into your eye)

Most people are eventually able to return to all their normal activities.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Important

Call the hospital or go to A&E if the pain, redness or blurriness gets worse after surgery. You may need further treatment.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of a detached retina

A detached retina is usually caused by changes to the jelly inside your eye, which can happen as you get older. This is called posterior vitreous detachment (PVD).

It's not clear exactly why PVD can lead to retinal detachment in some people and there's nothing you can do to prevent it. But it's more likely to happen if you:

  • are short-sighted
  • have had an eye operation (such as cataract surgery)
  • have had an eye injury
  • have a family history of retinal detachment
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

If your symptoms come back

You can get a detached retina more than once. Get medical help as soon as possible if the symptoms come back.

"}]}]}

"", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Dysphagia is\u00a0the medical term for swallowing difficulties.

Some people with dysphagia have problems swallowing certain foods or liquids, while others can't swallow at all.

Other signs of dysphagia include:

  • coughing or choking when eating or drinking
  • bringing food back up, sometimes through the nose
  • a sensation that food is stuck in your throat or chest
  • persistent drooling of saliva
  • being unable to chew food properly
  • a 'gurgly' wet sounding voice when eating or drinking

Over time, dysphagia can also cause symptoms such as weight loss and repeated chest infections.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to seek medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to seek medical advice

You should see your GP if you, or someone you care for, have difficulty swallowing or any other signs of dysphagia so you can get treatment to help with your symptoms.

Early investigation can also help to rule out other more serious conditions, such as oesophageal cancer.

Your GP will assess you and may refer you for further tests.

Read more about diagnosing dysphagia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treating dysphagia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating dysphagia

Treatment usually depends on the cause and type of dysphagia.

Many cases of dysphagia can be improved with careful management, but a cure isn't always possible. Treatments for dysphagia include:

  • speech and language therapy to learn new swallowing techniques
  • changing the consistency of food and liquids to make them safer to swallow
  • other forms of feeding \u2013 such as tube feeding through the nose or stomach
  • surgery to widen the oesophagus, by stretching it or inserting a plastic or metal tube (stent)

Read more about treating dysphagia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes of dysphagia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of dysphagia

Dysphagia is usually caused by another health condition, such as:

  • a condition that affects the nervous system, such as a stroke, head injury,\u00a0multiple sclerosis or\u00a0dementia
  • cancer\u00a0\u2013 such as mouth cancer\u00a0or oesophageal cancer
  • gastro-oesophageal reflux disease\u00a0(GORD)\u00a0\u2013 where stomach acid leaks back up into the\u00a0oesophagus

Children\u00a0can also have dysphagia as a result of a developmental or learning disability, such as cerebral palsy.

Read more about the causes of dysphagia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications of dysphagia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of dysphagia

Dysphagia can sometimes lead to further problems.

One of the most common problems is coughing or choking, when food goes down the "wrong way" and blocks your airway. This can lead to chest infections, such as aspiration pneumonia, which require urgent medical treatment.

Aspiration pneumonia can develop after accidentally inhaling something, such as a small piece of food.

Warning signs of aspiration pneumonia include:

  • a wet, gurgly voice while eating or drinking
  • coughing while eating or drinking
  • difficulty breathing \u2013 breathing may be rapid and shallow

If you, or someone you care for, have been diagnosed with dysphagia and you develop these symptoms, contact your treatment team immediately, or call NHS 111.

Dysphagia may mean that you avoid eating and drinking due to a fear of choking, which can lead to malnutrition and dehydration.

Dysphagia can also affect your quality of life because it may prevent you from enjoying meals and social occasions.

Dysphagia in children

If children with long-term dysphagia aren't eating enough, they may not get the essential nutrients they need for physical and mental development.

Children who have difficulty eating may also find meal times stressful, which may lead to behavioural problems.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

  • care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled - including family members

Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support.

Type 2 diabetes:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Type 2 diabetes", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Type 2 diabetes", "alternateName": ["Diabetes (type 2)"]}, "description": "Read about type 2 diabetes, a condition that causes a person's blood sugar level to become too high.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-08-18T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-08-18T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/", "name": "Type 2 diabetes", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-01T16:42:03+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/#overview", "description": "Type 2 diabetes is a condition that causes too much sugar in your blood. It can cause serious health problems if not treated.", "text": "

Symptoms of type 2 diabetes include needing to pee a lot, feeling thirsty all the time and feeling very tired.

Treatment for type 2 diabetes includes medicines and changes to your diet and activity levels to help control your blood sugar levels.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/symptoms/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of type 2 diabetes include needing to pee a lot, feeling thirsty all the time and feeling very tired.", "text": "

Many people have type 2 diabetes without realising. This is because symptoms do not necessarily make you feel unwell.

Symptoms of type 2 diabetes include:

  • peeing more than usual, particularly at night
  • feeling thirsty all the time
  • feeling very tired
  • losing weight without trying to
  • itching around your penis or vagina, or repeatedly getting thrush
  • cuts or wounds taking longer to heal
  • blurred vision
", "title": "Check if you have type 2 diabetes"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/understanding-medication/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatment for type 2 diabetes includes medicines and changes to your diet and activity levels to help control your blood sugar levels.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/understanding-medication/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatment for type 2 diabetes includes medicines and changes to your diet and activity levels to help control your blood sugar levels.", "text": "

Most people need medicine to control their type 2 diabetes.

Medicine helps keep your blood sugar level as normal as possible to prevent health problems. You may have to take it for the rest of your life.

Diabetes usually gets worse over time, so your medicine or dose may need to change.

Adjusting your diet and being active is usually necessary to keep your blood sugar level down.

", "title": "Medicines for type 2 diabetes"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/food-and-keeping-active/#self-care", "description": "Treatment for type 2 diabetes includes medicines and changes to your diet and activity levels to help control your blood sugar levels.", "text": "

A healthy diet and keeping active will help you manage your blood sugar level.

It'll also help you control your weight and generally feel better.

You can eat many types of foods

There's nothing you cannot eat if you have type 2 diabetes, but you'll have to limit certain foods.

You should:

  • eat a wide range of foods \u2013 including fruit, vegetables and some starchy foods like pasta
  • keep sugar, fat and salt to a minimum
  • eat breakfast, lunch and dinner every day \u2013 do not skip meals

If you need to change your diet, it might be easier to make small changes every week.

", "title": "Staying healthy if you have type 2 diabetes"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Type 2 diabetes", "alternativeHeadline": "What is type 2 diabetes?"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/getting-diagnosed/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Getting diagnosed"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/understanding-medication/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Understanding medicine"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/food-and-keeping-active/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Food and keeping active"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/going-regular-check-ups/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Going for regular check-ups"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/health-problems/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 6, "name": "Health problems"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/type-2-diabetes/finding-help-and-support/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 7, "name": "Finding help and support"}], "keywords": ["Hyperglycaemia", "Type 2 diabetes", "Gestational diabetes", "Diabetes", "Diabetic", "Healthy eating", "Insulin"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "
  • Type 2 diabetes is a common condition that causes the level of sugar (glucose) in the blood to become too high.
  • It can cause symptoms like excessive thirst, needing to pee a lot and tiredness. It can also increase your risk of getting serious problems with your eyes, heart and nerves.
  • It's a lifelong condition that can affect your everyday life. You may need to change your diet, take medicines and have regular check-ups.
  • It's caused by problems with a chemical in the body (hormone) called insulin. It's often linked to being overweight or inactive, or having a family history of type 2 diabetes.

Get the flu vaccine

Flu can be very serious if you have diabetes. Ask for your free flu jab at:

  • your GP surgery
  • a local pharmacy that has a flu vaccine service

Find out more about the flu vaccine

Vascular dementia:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vascular dementia", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vascular dementia", "alternateName": ["Dementia (vascular)"]}, "description": "Find out about vascular dementia, including what the symptoms are, how it's treated and what the outlook is.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-03-05T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-03-05T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/", "name": "Vascular dementia", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-17T10:41:31+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/#overview", "description": "Vascular dementia is a common type of dementia caused by reduced blood flow to the brain.", "text": "

Symptoms of vascular dementia include confusion, slow thinking and changes in your mood or behaviour.

There's no cure for vascular dementia, but a healthy lifestyle and medicines for related problems, such as high blood pressure, may help slow it down.

Vascular dementia is caused by reduced blood flow to the brain. It can be a result of a stroke, or the narrowing of the blood vessels in the brain.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of vascular dementia include confusion, slow thinking and changes in your mood or behaviour.", "text": "

Vascular dementia can start suddenly or begin slowly over time.

Symptoms include:

  • slowness of thought
  • difficulty with planning and understanding
  • problems with\u00a0concentration
  • changes to your mood, personality or behaviour
  • feeling disoriented and confused
  • difficulty walking and keeping balance
  • symptoms of Alzheimer's disease,\u00a0such as problems with memory and language (many people with vascular dementia also have Alzheimer's disease)

These problems can make daily activities increasingly difficult and someone with the condition may eventually be unable to look after themselves.

", "title": "Symptoms\u00a0of vascular dementia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/#treatments-summary", "description": "There's no cure for vascular dementia, but a healthy lifestyle and medicines for related problems, such as high blood pressure, may help slow it down.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/#treatments-other", "description": "There's no cure for vascular dementia, but a healthy lifestyle and medicines for related problems, such as high blood pressure, may help slow it down.", "text": "

There's currently\u00a0no cure for vascular dementia and there's no way to reverse any loss of brain cells that happened before\u00a0the condition\u00a0was diagnosed.

But treatment can sometimes help slow down vascular dementia.

Treatment aims to tackle the underlying cause, which\u00a0may reduce the speed at which brain cells are lost.

This will often involve:

  • eating a healthy, balanced diet
  • losing weight if you're overweight
  • stopping smoking
  • getting fit
  • cutting down on alcohol
  • taking medicines, such as those used to treat high blood pressure, lower cholesterol\u00a0or prevent\u00a0blood clots

Other treatments,\u00a0including physiotherapy, occupational therapy, dementia activities (such as memory cafes) and\u00a0psychological therapies,\u00a0can\u00a0help reduce the impact of any existing problems.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for vascular dementia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/#causes", "description": "Vascular dementia is caused by reduced blood flow to the brain. It can be a result of a stroke, or the narrowing of the blood vessels in the brain.", "text": "

Vascular dementia is caused by reduced blood flow to the brain, which damages and eventually kills brain cells.\u00a0

This can\u00a0happen as a result of:

  • narrowing and blockage of\u00a0the small blood vessels inside the brain
  • a single\u00a0stroke, where the blood supply to part of the brain is suddenly cut off
  • lots of \"mini strokes\" (also called transient ischaemic attacks, or TIAs) that cause tiny but widespread damage to the brain

In many cases, these problems are linked to underlying conditions, such as\u00a0high blood pressure and\u00a0diabetes,\u00a0and\u00a0lifestyle factors, such as smoking and being overweight.

Tackling these might reduce your risk of vascular dementia in later life, although\u00a0it's not yet clear exactly how much your risk of dementia can be reduced.

", "title": "Causes\u00a0of vascular dementia"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Vascular dementia", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vascular-dementia/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Dementia", "Stroke", "High blood pressure", "memory loss", "Vascular dementia", "Brain", "mini stroke", "Alzheimer's disease"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vascular dementia is a common\u00a0type of dementia caused by reduced blood flow to the brain. It's estimated to affect around 150,000 people in the UK.

Dementia is the name for problems with mental abilities caused by gradual changes and damage in the brain. It's rare in people under 65.

Vascular dementia\u00a0tends to get worse over time, although it's sometimes possible to slow it down.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and dementia:

  • Alzheimer's Society: Coronavirus information for people affected by dementia
  • Dementia UK: Coronavirus questions and answers
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of vascular dementia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vascular dementia can start suddenly or begin slowly over time.

Symptoms include:

  • slowness of thought
  • difficulty with planning and understanding
  • problems with\u00a0concentration
  • changes to your mood, personality or behaviour
  • feeling disoriented and confused
  • difficulty walking and keeping balance
  • symptoms of Alzheimer's disease,\u00a0such as problems with memory and language (many people with vascular dementia also have Alzheimer's disease)

These problems can make daily activities increasingly difficult and someone with the condition may eventually be unable to look after themselves.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Getting\u00a0medical advice", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See a GP if you think you have early symptoms of dementia, especially if you're over 65 years of age.

If it's found at an early stage, treatment may be able to stop vascular dementia getting worse, or at least slow it down.

If you're worried about\u00a0someone else, encourage them to make an appointment with a GP and perhaps suggest that you go with them.

Your GP\u00a0can do some simple checks to try to find the cause of your symptoms. They can\u00a0refer you to a\u00a0memory\u00a0clinic or another specialist for\u00a0further tests\u00a0if needed.

Find out more about how to get dementia diagnosis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Tests\u00a0for vascular dementia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There's no single test for vascular dementia.

The tests that are needed to make a diagnosis include:

  • an assessment of symptoms \u2013 for example, whether these are typical\u00a0symptoms of vascular dementia
  • a full medical history, including asking about a history of conditions related to vascular dementia, such as\u00a0strokes or\u00a0high blood pressure
  • an assessment of mental abilities\u00a0\u2013 this will usually involve several tasks and questions
  • a brain scan, such as an\u00a0MRI scan or\u00a0CT scan, to look for any changes that have happened in your brain

Find out more about the tests used to diagnose dementia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments\u00a0for vascular dementia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There's currently\u00a0no cure for vascular dementia and there's no way to reverse any loss of brain cells that happened before\u00a0the condition\u00a0was diagnosed.

But treatment can sometimes help slow down vascular dementia.

Treatment aims to tackle the underlying cause, which\u00a0may reduce the speed at which brain cells are lost.

This will often involve:

  • eating a healthy, balanced diet
  • losing weight if you're overweight
  • stopping smoking
  • getting fit
  • cutting down on alcohol
  • taking medicines, such as those used to treat high blood pressure, lower cholesterol\u00a0or prevent\u00a0blood clots

Other treatments,\u00a0including physiotherapy, occupational therapy, dementia activities (such as memory cafes) and\u00a0psychological therapies,\u00a0can\u00a0help reduce the impact of any existing problems.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Outlook\u00a0for vascular dementia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vascular dementia will usually get worse over time. This can happen in sudden steps, with periods in between where the symptoms do not change much, but it's difficult to predict when this will happen.

Home-based help\u00a0will usually be needed, and some people will eventually need care in a nursing home.

Although treatment can help, vascular dementia can significantly shorten life expectancy.

But this is highly variable, and many people live for several years with the condition, or die from some other cause.

If you or a loved one has been diagnosed with dementia, remember that you're not alone. The NHS and social services,\u00a0as well as voluntary organisations, can provide advice and support for you and your family.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes\u00a0of vascular dementia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vascular dementia is caused by reduced blood flow to the brain, which damages and eventually kills brain cells.\u00a0

This can\u00a0happen as a result of:

  • narrowing and blockage of\u00a0the small blood vessels inside the brain
  • a single\u00a0stroke, where the blood supply to part of the brain is suddenly cut off
  • lots of "mini strokes" (also called transient ischaemic attacks, or TIAs) that cause tiny but widespread damage to the brain

In many cases, these problems are linked to underlying conditions, such as\u00a0high blood pressure and\u00a0diabetes,\u00a0and\u00a0lifestyle factors, such as smoking and being overweight.

Tackling these might reduce your risk of vascular dementia in later life, although\u00a0it's not yet clear exactly how much your risk of dementia can be reduced.
